Italy |- style="background:#D0E7FF;" |} == See also == *[[International Canoe Federation]] *[[British Canoe Union]] == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == {{Commons category|Kayak polo}} * [http://www.canoepolosyracuse2016.com Official 2016 World Championship page] * [http://www.canoepolo.com/ CanoePolo.com] — a canoe polo forum * [http://www.polopage.com/ PoloPage.com] – Canoe Polo Videos * [http://www.canoeicf.com/icf/Aboutoursport/Canoe-Polo/More-on-Canoe-Polo/Technical-Information.html Technical Information and rules] from the [[International Canoe Federation]] * {{YouTube|id=m3PMzY—ZkQ|title=GER vs ITA, 2010 World Championships, Milan}}—International Canoe Federation clip === Governing bodies === * [https://web.archive.org/web/20060829054231/http://www.canoe.org.au/default.asp?MenuID=Disciplines%2F97%2F0%2CCanoe_Polo%2F77%2F2230 Australian Canoe Polo]—official webpage * [http://www.canoepolo.org.uk/ Official site of British Canoe Polo] * [http://www.canoepolo.ca/ Official Canadian Canoe Polo site]—contains numerous links to local clubs * [http://www.canoepolo.ie/ Official site of Irish Canoe Polo] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20130520213037/http://canoepolonz.org.nz/ Official site of the New Zealand Canoe Polo Assn] * [http://www.kanupolo.de/ Official site of German Canoe Polo] * [http://www.canoepolo.ir/ Official site of Iran Canoe Polo] * [http://canoepolo.ru/ Official site of Russian Canoe Polo] * [http://canoepolo.ir/ Persian site about canoe polo training] * [http://canoepolo.org.ua/ Official site of Ukranian canoe polo] {{Sports of the World Games program}} {{Canoeing and kayaking}} {{Water polo}} {{Team Sport}} {{Main world championships}} [[Category:Canoe polo| ]] [[Category:Canoeing disciplines]] [[Category:Water polo]] [[Category:Team sports]] [[Category:Ball games]] [[Category:Sports originating in the United Kingdom]]

revision.text:
{{Motorsport venue| Name = Charlotte Speedway | Image = USGSCharlotteSpeedway1950aerial.png | Location = [[Charlotte, North Carolina|Charlotte]], [[North Carolina]] | Opened = 1949| Closed = October 17, 1956| Demolished = N/A| Events = First NASCAR Race In 1949| Layout1 = Oval | Length_km = 1.2 | Length_mi = 0.75 | }}''For the current NASCAR track in Charlotte, North Carolina, see [[Charlotte Motor Speedway]].''
'''Charlotte Speedway''' was the site of [[NASCAR]]'s first Strictly Stock (now [[Monster Energy NASCAR Cup Series]]) race on June 19, 1949. The [[Daytona Beach Road Course]] held the first race sanctioned by NASCAR in 1948. The track was a few miles west of the [[NASCAR Hall of Fame]], on Little Rock Road. It was owned by Carl C. Allison Sr. and his wife, Catherine Montgomery Allison. The track was forced to close when construction of Interstate 85 took its parking area.
==Event details== Charlotte Speedway was a three-quarter mile long [[Dirt track racing|dirt track]]. The first event in 1949 was a {{convert|150|mi|km|sing=on}} race. Other events were 100, 113, or {{convert|150|mi|km}} long.
==NASCAR history== Twelve events were held at the track between 1949 and 1956. Winners at the track include: [[Jim Roper]] (1), [[Tim Flock]] (1), [[Curtis Turner]] (2), [[Herb Thomas]] (2), [[Dick Passwater]] (1), [[Buck Baker]] (3), [[Fonty Flock]] (1), and [[Speedy Thompson]] (1).
===1949=== {{main|1949 NASCAR Strictly Stock Series Race 1}} [[Bob Flock]] won the pole. [[Glenn Dunaway]] was declared the original winner, but a post-race inspection revealed that his car was fitted with illegal springs, causing NASCAR to disqualify him. [[Jim Roper]] was declared the official winner of the event. Roper would only compete in one more NASCAR event in his career. Other famous drivers to finish in the Top 10 include: [[Fonty Flock]], [[Red Byron]], [[Tim Flock]], and [[Curtis Turner]]. Famous drivers to finish outside of the Top 10 include: [[Buck Baker]], [[Jack Smith (NASCAR driver)|Jack Smith]], [[Lee Petty]], [[Herb Thomas]], and [[Bob Flock]]. [[Sara Christian]] finished 14th to become the first female to start in a NASCAR race.
==Past winners==
===1950-02=== * 1950 Tim Flock
===1949-01=== * 1949 [[Jim Roper]]
==External links== *[http://www.racing-reference.info/tracks?id=087 Track history and details at racing-reference.info]

{{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Cramton Bowl | image = Cramton Bowl Feb 2012 03.jpg | image_size = 250px | caption = Cramton Bowl in 2012 | location = 1022 Madison Avenue,
[[Montgomery, Alabama]] 36107 | coordinates = {{coord|32.37949|-86.293002|type:landmark_scale:10000_region:US|display=it}} | opened = 1922 | owner = City of Montgomery | operator = | seating_capacity = 25,000 | surface = UBU Speed S5 | tenants = [[Camellia Bowl (2014–present)|Camellia Bowl]] ([[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]]) (2014–)
[[Blue–Gray Football Classic]] (1939–2001)
[[Montgomery Public Schools]]
[[Alabama State Hornets football|Alabama State Hornets]] ([[Southwestern Athletic Conference|SWAC]]) (1923–2012)
[[Faulkner University|Faulkner Eagles]] ([[National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics|NAIA]]) (2007–present)
[[Alabama Crimson Tide football|Alabama Crimson Tide]] ([[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]]) (1922–1954)
[[Chattanooga Lookouts]] ([[Southern League (baseball)|Southern League]]) (1943)
[[Montgomery Rebels]] ([[Southeastern League]]) (1938–1949)
[[Montgomery Bombers]] ([[Southeastern League]]) (1937)
[[Montgomery Lions]] ([[Southeastern League]]) (1927–1930) }} '''Cramton Bowl''' is a 25,000-seat [[stadium]] located in [[Montgomery, Alabama]]. Cramton Bowl opened in 1922 as a [[Baseball park|baseball stadium]] and has been home to [[Major League Baseball]] [[spring training]], and to [[minor league baseball]]. Today, however, its primary use is for [[American football]]. It is the host of the annual [[Camellia Bowl (2014–present)|Camellia Bowl]] for the [[NCAA Division I Football Bowl Subdivision]], and of Montgomery's five high school squads. It was home to the [[Blue–Gray Football Classic]], an all-star game usually played on Christmas Day, the [[Alabama State Hornets football]] team, and hosted the first ever football game played under the lights in the South.[http://www.montgomeryal.gov/index.aspx?page=188 City of Montgomery, website] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110721050054/http://www.montgomeryal.gov/index.aspx?page=188 |date=2011-07-21 }}{{cite news|last=McMurphy|first=Brett|title=Bowl created for MAC, Sun Belt|publisher=ESPN.com|url=http://espn.go.com/college-football/story/_/id/9581531/espn-creates-bowl-mac-sun-belt-teams|accessdate=August 20, 2013|date=August 19, 2013}} ==Stadium history== [[File:Cramton Bowl 1921.png|thumb|right|An architect's sketch of Cramton Bowl, 1921]] Cramton Bowl is named for Fred J. Cramton, a local businessman who donated the land on which the stadium is built."City Dads Accept Cramton Bowl Gift", ''Montgomery Advertiser'', February 9, 1921. After a conversation with friends about the need for a baseball stadium, Cramton donated his sanitary landfill to the city so a facility could be constructed there. The city held the land for a time and then returned it, stating that Cramton's stadium idea was too big of a project for the city to undertake. Cramton then decided to take matters into his own hands; with the help of the [[Junior Chamber of Commerce]], Cramton raised $33,000 to build the sports venue.{{cite web | url = http://mymaxmore.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=120:the-cramton-conversion&catid=1:current&Itemid=32 | title = The Cramton Conversion | accessdate = 2011-05-10 | author = Fields, Tommy }} ===Capacity=== [[Seating capacity]] was expanded in 1929 to 7,991. More additions were made in 1946, increasing the seating capacity to 12,000. East stands were added in 1962 bringing the seating capacity up to 24,000. After new renovations were completed in July 2011 the capacity was reduced to 21,000.[http://alsportscapital.com/facility/cramton_bowl Central Alabama Sports Commission] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110811093838/http://alsportscapital.com/facility/cramton_bowl |date=2011-08-11 }} ==Baseball== [[File:Cramton Bowl baseball.jpg|thumb|Cramton Bowl during a baseball game in the 1920s or 1930s]] The first baseball game played on the new field was in May 1922 between [[Auburn University]] and [[Vanderbilt University]]. Shortly after its completion in 1922 the [[Philadelphia Athletics]] decided to move their spring training operations from [[Eagle Pass, Texas]] to Montgomery. They used the facility for their 1923 and 1924 spring training and exhibition games before moving to a newer stadium in [[Fort Myers, Florida]]. After the departure of the [[Philadelphia Athletics]] spring training, [[Minor League Baseball]]'s newly formed [[Southeastern League]] placed a team in Montgomery. They became known as the [[Montgomery Lions]]. The Lions played in Cramton Bowl from 1927 to 1930. There was no team from 1931 to 1936 due to problems within the Southeastern League and the ongoing negative economic effects of the [[Great Depression]]. The team returned for the 1937 season as the [[Montgomery Bombers]] and garnered their first [[major league baseball]] affiliation with the [[Cleveland Indians]]. The Indians pulled out for the 1938 season and were replaced by the [[Philadelphia Phillies]]. After one season the Phillies dropped their affiliation; the team became a co-op franchise and were renamed the [[Montgomery Rebels]]. In 1943, the Rebels would disband due to the manpower shortage caused by World War II. On July 11 of that year, the [[Chattanooga Lookouts]] moved their home games to Cramton Bowl to play out the rest of the season.{{cite web|url=http://fultonhistory.com/Newspaper%2018/New%20York%20NY%20Sun/New%20York%20NY%20Sun%201943/New%20York%20NY%20Sun%201943%20-%200568.pdf|title=Senators shift Lookout franchise|last=The Old Scout|date=July 16, 1943|publisher=New York Sun|accessdate=19 September 2013}} The Lookouts managed to move back to Chattanooga and reverse the trend of declining attendance sometime later in the 1940s. The Rebels returned in 1946 through 1949 before moving to the newly constructed [[Paterson Field]] located just across the street.[https://www.baseball-reference.com/minors/park.cgi?id=AL031 Baseball-Reference][http://www.digitalballparks.com/Southern/Cramton.html Digital Ballparks] The eighth and deciding game of the [[1943 Negro World Series]] was held at the Cramton Bowl, with the [[Homestead Grays]] defeating the [[Birmingham Black Barons]], 8-4. ==Football== On September 23, 1927, Cramton Bowl became the site of the very first game played "under the lights" in the South with Cloverdale taking on Pike Road High School. Former superintendent D. H. "Sarge" Caraker remembers fondly, "[We] used dishpans for reflectors and sent to California for the lamps. We drew 7,200 people from all over the South to see it." ===College football=== Cramton Bowl was host to all home games for [[Alabama State Hornets football]], and was the host to all of those for the [[Faulkner University]] Eagles. It was also home to the [[Turkey Day Classic]] and in 2009 hosted the inaugural [[HBCU]] [[All-star]] Bowl. Cramton Bowl also provided a location for [[Alabama Crimson Tide football]] home games in the capital city. The Crimson Tide played home games at Cramton Bowl in the [[1922 Alabama Crimson Tide football team|1922]] through [[1932 Alabama Crimson Tide football team|1932 seasons]], in [[1934 Alabama Crimson Tide football team|1934]], from [[1944 Alabama Crimson Tide football team|1944]] through [[1946 Alabama Crimson Tide football team|1946]] and again from [[1951 Alabama Crimson Tide football team|1951]] through [[1954 Alabama Crimson Tide football team|1954]]. Alabama's all-time record at Cramton Bowl was 17 wins and 3 losses.{{cite web | url = http://www.rolltide.com/sports/m-footbl/archive/m-footbl-results-archive.html | title = All-time Football Results | accessdate = 2009-01-02 | author = University of Alabama Sports Information }} Cramton Bowl probably achieved its greatest fame as the home of the [[Blue–Gray Football Classic]], an annual [[college football]] [[all-star]] game which was held there each December from 1938 until 2001. Beginning in 2014, Cramton Bowl began hosting the [[Camellia Bowl (2014–present)|Camellia Bowl]], a college football [[bowl game]] which features teams from the [[Sun Belt Conference]] and [[Mid-American Conference]].https://www.sbnation.com/college-football/2013/8/19/4636402/montgomery-bowl-game-sun-belt-machttp://collegefootballtalk.nbcsports.com/2013/08/19/newly-created-camellia-bowl-will-feature-mac-sun-belt-teams/ ===High school football=== Several area high schools call Cramton Bowl home including the [[Jefferson Davis High School (Montgomery, Alabama)|Jeff Davis Volunteers]], [[Sidney Lanier High School|Lanier Poets]], [[Robert E. Lee High School (Montgomery, Alabama)|Lee Generals]], Park Crossing High School Thunderbirds, and [[George Washington Carver High School (Montgomery, Alabama)|Carver Wolverines]]. In July 2011, Cramton Bowl hosted the [[Alabama High School Athletic Association]] Alabama All-Stars Sports Week football game. ==2011 renovations== By the start of the 21st century, Cramton Bowl was widely regarded as being functionally obsolete for major sporting events. The stadium's relatively small capacity was not a concern as much as its age and condition. The stadium was not well maintained for most of its history, and by the dawn of the new millennium it was actually crumbling. These issues were factors, although not the predominant ones, in the Blue-Gray Game not being held in 2002 and its subsequent relocation in 2003 to [[Troy University]]'s [[Movie Gallery Stadium]], about 50 miles (80 km) from Montgomery. In mid-2010 the City of Montgomery approved a measure for a $10 million renovation and addition to Cramton Bowl. The renovations planned for Cramton Bowl were a unique mix of the old and the new. The old structure was revamped and updated with four entrances, a state-of-the-art press box, an aesthetically enhanced plaza area, and a "Walk of Fame," which celebrates Montgomery's sports history and houses various articles of historic sports memorabilia. Perhaps the most important and impressive addition was the {{convert|90,000|sqft|m2|adj=on}} multi-purpose sports facility. Demolition of the north endzone and press box began in late November 2010, which was phase one of the project. Phase two began in early January 2011 as crews removed an existing brick wall from the south endzone and dismantled the scoreboard to make way for the new multi-purpose sports facility. Work on the stadium was completed in 2011 while the new multi-purpose facility was finished in 2012.{{cite web | url = http://www.montgomeryadvertiser.com/article/20101128/SPORTS0403/11280347/1002/rss03 | title = Cramton Bowl to get a face lift: Stadium to be joined by an indoor arena | accessdate = 2010-11-28 | author = Gayle, Tim | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://archive.is/20130208121159/http://www.montgomeryadvertiser.com/article/20101128/SPORTS0403/11280347/1002/rss03 | archivedate = 2013-02-08 | df = }} {{cite web | url = http://www.montgomeryadvertiser.com/article/20110127/SPORTS/101270341/1002/rss03 | title = Cramton Bowl renovation work reveals hidden rooms | accessdate = 2011-01-27 | author = Gayle, Tim | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110219202324/http://www.montgomeryadvertiser.com/article/20110127/SPORTS/101270341/1002/rss03 | archivedate = 2011-02-19 | df = }} ==References== {{commons category|Cramton Bowl}} {{Reflist}} {{Alabama State University}} {{Alabama State Hornets football navbox}} {{Southwestern Athletic Conference football venue navbox}} {{Alabama Crimson Tide football navbox}} {{Alabama college football venues}} {{Camellia Bowl navbox}} {{NCAA Division I FBS bowl game stadium navbox}} [[Category:College football venues]] [[Category:High school football venues in the United States]] [[Category:Alabama Crimson Tide football venues]] [[Category:Alabama State Hornets football]] [[Category:Faulkner Eagles football]] [[Category:American football venues in Alabama]] [[Category:Sports venues in Montgomery, Alabama]] [[Category:Alabama State Hornets and Lady Hornets sports venues]] [[Category:Negro league baseball venues still standing]] [[Category:1922 establishments in Alabama]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1922]]

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2016}} {{Use British English|date=October 2016}} {{Infobox stadium | name = Derby Greyhound Stadium | nickname = | logo_image = | logo_caption = | image = New County Gaol, South Street, Derby, England.jpg | image_size = 250px | caption = Former stadium entrance, originally the prison gates; preserved facade, pictured 2008 | fullname = | former_names = | location = Vernon Street, [[Derby]] | coordinates = 52°55'23.2"N 1°29'30.5"W<!-- {{Coord|LAT|LON|type:landmark|display=inline,title}} --> | broke_ground = | built = | opened = <!-- {{Start date|df=yes|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> 1933 | renovated = | expanded = | closed = 1988 | demolished = | owner = Preston Greyhound Racing Association | operator = | surface = | scoreboard = | cost = | architect = | project_manager = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | main_contractors = | capacity = | suites = | record_attendance = | dimensions = | acreage = | volume = | tenants = | embedded = | website = <!-- {{URL|example.com}} --> | publictransit = }}'''Derby Greyhound Stadium''' or '''Derby Stadium''' was a [[greyhound racing]] venue in [[Derby]], England.<ref>{{cite book|last=Genders|first=Roy|title=The Encyclopedia of Greyhound Racing|year=1981|publisher=Pelham Books Ltd|isbn=07207-1106-1}}</ref>
==Origins== A full century before turning into a greyhound stadium the site was used as the county gaol and called the [[Derby Gaol|Vernon Street Prison]]. It was a six acre site on South Street backing onto Uttoxeter Old Road and cost £65,000 to build. The entrance was at the end of Vernon Street and the construction took six years to complete opening in 1827. The walls were 25 feet high enclosing three acres of land and the gaol held over 300 prisoners.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.old-maps.co.uk/#/Map/434264/336307/13/100155|title=OS Town Plan, Derby, Derbyshire 1883|publisher=old-maps.co.uk}}</ref>
It continued to serve as a prison until 1916 but was then used as a military prison. The buildings and cells inside the boundary walls were demolished in 1929 but the curtain wall and large entrance. Within five years the Preston Greyhound Racing Association had purchased the site and built a greyhound stadium within the walls.<ref>{{cite book|last=Tarter|first=P Howard|title=Greyhound Racing Encyclopedia|page =58|year=1949|publisher=Fleet Publishing Company Ltd}}</ref>
==Opening== The company who had just opened their [[Preston Greyhound Stadium|Preston]] track in May 1932 set an opening date of 29 April 1933.<ref>{{cite news|title=Derby Stadium Dog Racing|url=http://www.britishnewspaperarchive.co.uk/viewer/bl/0000520/19330501/080/0007|accessdate=18 January 2015|work=Derby Evening Telegraph|date=1 May 1933|via = [[British Newspaper Archive]]|subscription=yes}}</ref> The first manager was Ted Rimmer (one of the famous Rimmer brothers within the industry) and facilities included two clubs, one in the grandstand and one in the popular enclosure. The first ever winner was 2-1 shot Tramore Lad over 260 yards after defeating 6-4 favourite Santober by one length in 17.31. Many of the early races were just four dog events.<ref>{{cite book|last=Barnes|first=Julia|title=Daily Mirror Greyhound Fact File|page =93|year=1988|publisher=Ringpress Books|isbn=0-948955-15-5}}</ref>
The circumference of the track was 385 yards which was laid out on the former exercise yard for the prisoners, other distances were 460 and 650 yards. The onsite kennels adjacent to the track backed onto Sims Avenue; the old prison officer's quarters were now houses for the trainers, a cookhouse, storage and staff rooms.
==History== Trainer Charlie Green provided the track with their first major winner when Silver Wire won the 1939 [[Scurry Gold Cup]] at [[Clapton Stadium]]. Another track trainer Harold Broadbent looked after the greyhounds housed in the adjoining stadium kennels owned by the company and he would eventually become the head of the [[Royal Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals|RSPCA]]. After the [[World War II|war]] a greyhound called Keepers Remorse raced a remarkable 409 times, finishing second 98 times and in 1947 the [[Tote board|tote]] turnover was £452,808.<ref>{{cite book|title=Particulars of Licensed tracks, table 1 Licensed Dog Racecourses|year=1947|publisher=Licensing Authorities}}</ref>
Racing Managers included Lieutenant-Colonel Prior and George Turnpenny who arrived from [[Willenhall Greyhound Stadium|Willenhall]] in the 1950s. The next milestone came in 1968 after the Pat Murphy trained Malaria won the Midland Flat Championship. During the sixties race nights were on Wednesday and Saturday evenings and facilities included three buffet bars and two licensed bars. The circuit circumference was re-measured at 378 yards. In the 1970s Barry Davis was Racing Manager and two principal events were introduced, they were the Derby Plate over 420 metres and the Derby Vase over 590 metres<ref>{{cite book|last=Genders|first=Roy|title=The Encyclopedia of Greyhound Racing|pages =47–48|year=1981|publisher=Pelham Books Ltd|isbn=07207-1106-1}}</ref>
==Closure== In 1984 the ageing stadium was bought by Terry Corden for £300,000, Corden had taken over as General Manager in 1979. Peter Robinson was brought in as Racing Manager and the only remaining trainers housed at the track kennels were Tom Harrison and Pat Murphy following the departure of Frank Heald and Peter Corbett. Corden sold the stadium for £1 million in 1988 to JF Miller properties and Heights of Abraham Limited. Within two years the Derby City Council received a planning application for redevelopment.<ref>{{cite book|last=Genders|first=Roy|title=NGRC book of Greyhound Racing|page =63|year=1990|publisher=Pelham Books Ltd|isbn=0-7207-1804-X}}</ref>
The last race meeting was held on Saturday 7 December 1988 (the same year as former sister track Preston).<ref>{{cite book|last=Betts|first=Bob|title=The Sporting Life Greyhound Annual|page =86|year=1992|publisher=The Sporting Life|isbn=0-948955-22-8}}</ref> Today the area is very smart with office buildings contained within the redeveloped area. A beautifully restored entrance called Vernon Gate still marks the entrance of the prison and greyhound stadium.
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{English greyhound tracks}}
[[Category:Defunct greyhound racing venues in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Defunct sports venues in Derbyshire]] [[Category:Sports venues in Derby]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1933]] [[Category:1933 establishments in England]]

{{Infobox venue | name = Estadio El Teniente-Codelco | nickname = ''Templo de las Ilusiones'' (Temple of Illusions)
''El Mundialista de Rancagua'' (The World Cup Stadium of Rancagua) | logo_image = [[File:El Teniente Logo.png|275px]] | logo_caption = | image = File:Desfile_2_de_Octubre_Bicentenario_Batalla_Rancagua_01.JPG | image_size = 275px | caption = The stadium in October 2014. | fullname = Estadio El Teniente-Codelcohttp://www.ohigginsfc.cl/2014/10/24/venta-de-entradas-para-llenar-el-teniente-ante-huachipato/ | former_names = Estadio Braden Copper Co. (1947–1971)
Estadio Parque El Teniente (1971–2014) | location = [[Rancagua]], [[Chile]] | coordinates = {{Coord|34|10|39.95|S|70|44|15.79|W|type:landmark|display=inline,title}} | broke_ground = 1 June 1945 | built = 1945–1947 (2 years) | opened = 1947 | expanded = 1962 | demolished = 2013 | renovated = 1995, 2013–14 | reopened = 6 March 2014 | owner = [[Codelco]] | operator = [[Codelco|Codelco El Teniente]] | surface = Grass (natural) | scoreboard = Digital ([[LED]]) | cost = $9,900,000 | architect = Gerardo Marambio
Claudio Aceituno
Pablo Allende
Pedro Pinochet | project_manager = IND–Chilestadios | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = Cerinco | main_contractors = | capacity = 13,849{{cite web|url=http://www.conmebol.com/es/copa-america-2015|title=Copa América 2015|work=conmebol.com}} | suites = 750 seats | record_attendance = | dimensions = 105 x 68 m | acreage = | tenants = [[O'Higgins F.C.|O'Higgins]] (1955–present) | embedded = | website = [http://www.ohigginsfc.cl/ www.ohigginsfc.cl] }} '''Estadio El Teniente''', also known as '''Estadio El Teniente-Codelco''' for sponsorship reasons, is a [[multi-purpose stadium]] in [[Rancagua]], [[Chile]]. It is currently used mostly for [[football (soccer)|football]] matches. The stadium actually holds approximately 13,000 people and was built in 1945 with the name [[Braden Copper Company]] Stadium ''(Estadio Braden Copper Co.)''. The stadium is the home stadium for [[O'Higgins F.C.|O'Higgins]], the team of the city of [[Rancagua]].{{cite web|url=http://www.worldstadiums.com/south_america/countries/chile.shtml|title=Stadiums in Chile|publisher=Worldstadiums.com|accessdate=21 September 2011}} The stadium hosted seven matches of [[1962 FIFA World Cup]], where played matches of the group stage and quarter-finals. In 2013, the stadium was renovated for hosting the [[2015 Copa América]], to be played in [[Chile]]. Two matches of the group stage will be played in this stadium. ==History== ===Construction=== [[File:Estadio Rancagua (Chile) - mayo de 1962.jpg|left|thumb|250px|The stadium in [[El Gráfico]] magazine in 1962.]] The stadium, since its construction, was owned by the U.S. copper mining company [[Braden Copper Company]], which operated the mineral-extraction complex "El Teniente". The designation of the Braden Copper Stadium to host matches in the [[1962 FIFA World Cup]] was due to an emergency. Indeed, the [[1960 Valdivia earthquake]] severely damaged or destroyed facilities in some of the originally-designated host cities of the FIFA World Cup in 1962 including [[Talca]], [[Concepción, Chile|Concepción]], [[Talcahuano]] and [[Valdivia]], which caused the original schedule to be discarded and forced its almost complete modification. Further, [[Antofagasta]] and [[Valparaíso]] were deterred from fulfilling their offers to host because they could not feasibly construct self-funded stadiums, a condition that had been imposed by the Federation due to its own lack of resources. However, given the bleak outlook for the organization, the U.S. mining interests allowed the use of their stadium in [[Rancagua]]. [[File:Estadio El Teniente 2009.jpg|250px|right|thumb|The old stadium in a match against [[Cobreloa]].]] ===Nationalisation of copper=== The [[Government of Chile]] acquired in 1967 51% of the shares of Braden Copper Co., as part of the general [[nationalization]] of copper, which concluded in 1971. Therefore, the ownership and management of the "Estadio Braden Copper" passed to the state-owned coroporation [[Codelco|Codelco Chile]], which led to the name change to the current one. ===New stadium=== On May 21, 2008, the then-[[President of Chile|president]] [[Michelle Bachelet]] announced the "Red de Estadios para el [[Bicentennial of Chile|Bicentenario]]", a programme in which w new stadiums were built and upgrades planned for others, among which was the Estadio El Teniente. However, remodeling El Teniente was not executed during the term of Bachelet, although this was projected, due to the [[2010 Chilean earthquake]].{{cite web|url=http://www.elrancahuaso.cl/noticia/deporte/estadio-el-teniente-por-fin-se-cumplira-el-sueno-de-rancagua|title=Estadio El Teniente: Por fin se cumplirá el sueño de Rancagua|work=El Rancahuaso.cl, Noticias de Rancagua y O'Higgins}} On September 2, 2012, President [[Sebastian Piñera]] announced in Rancagua the final draft of the plans for remodelling the stadium, which will have a capacity of 15 000 spectators. {{cite web|url=http://www.gob.cl/destacados/2012/09/02/mandatario-presenta-proyecto-de-remodelacion-del-estadio-el-teniente-de-rancagua.htm|title=Gobierno de Chile|work=Gobierno de Chile|accessdate=31 July 2015}} Construction began on February 19, 2013, and delivery is planned for early 2014.{{cite web|url=http://eltipografo.cl/2013/02/comenzo-el-proceso-de-remodelacion-del-estadio-el-teniente/|title=Comenzó el proceso de remodelación del estadio El Teniente|work=eltipografo.cl}} The [[Asociación Nacional de Fútbol Profesional]] (ANFP) announced in December 2012 that El Teniente had been selected to host the [[2015 Copa América]], along with [[Santiago]], [[Antofagasta]], [[La Serena, Chile|La Serena]], [[Valparaíso]], [[Viña del Mar]], [[Concepción, Chile|Concepción]] and [[Temuco]]. Host venue contested with the city of [[Talca]], however Rancagua was chosen due to its closer proximity to the Chilean capital.{{cite web|url=http://www.elrancaguino.cl/rancaguino/noticias_deportes.php?cod=2602|title=Rancagua será sede de Copa América|work=elrancaguino.cl}} ====Inaugural match==== In the inaugural match, [[O'Higgins F.C.|O'Higgins]] played against [[Club Atlético Lanús|Lanús]] for the week 6 of the [[2014 Copa Libertadores]]. The final result was 0–0, marking the elimination of the club from the competition, as they needed a victory to advance to the next round.{{cite web|url=http://www.capodeprovincia.cl/2014/04/el-capo-de-america-se-despide-de-la.html|title="Chau" Libertadores 2014…|work=Capo de Provincia}} {{footballbox collapsible |round=[[2014 Copa Libertadores]]
Week 6 |date=8 April 2014 |time= 22:00 |team1=[[O'Higgins F.C.|O'Higgins]] |score= 0–0 |report=[http://www.capodeprovincia.cl/2014/04/el-capo-de-america-se-despide-de-la.html Report] |team2=[[Club Atlético Lanús|Lanús]] |goals1= [[Pablo Calandria|Calandria]] {{penmiss}} 86' |goals2= |stadium= El Teniente |location= [[Rancagua]], [[Chile]] |attendance= 10,651 |referee= Wilton Sampaio ([[Brasil]]) |motm= |result= |stack= }} ==Sectors of the stadium== The stadium has 5 sectors since her renovation, the Palco has 375 seats, and the totality of the other four sectors are 13,464. * Angostura (North Side) * Marquesina (West Side) * Andes (East Side) * Rengo (South Side) * Palco (VIP suite) [[File:ElTeniente.jpg|550px|center|thumb|Map of the sectors of the stadium]] ==1962 World Cup== {{main article|1962 FIFA World Cup}} [[File:1451 soccer 170.png|175px|right|thumb|Commemorative stamp of the match between [[Argentina]] and [[Bulgaria]], played at the Estadio El Teniente.]] The Estadio El Teniente hosted seven games during the [[1962 FIFA World Cup]], every game of [[1962 FIFA World Cup#Group 4|Group 4]] and a [[1962 FIFA World Cup#Quarter-finals|quarterfinal.]] Teams which played in this stadium for the [[1962 FIFA World Cup]]: * {{fb|ARG|alt}} * {{fb|BUL|1946}} * {{fb|HUN}} * {{fb|ENG}} * {{fb|TCH}} ===Matches=== ====Group 4==== {{Football box |date = 30 May 1962 |time = 15:00 [[Time in Chile|CLT]] ([[UTC-04]]) |team1 = {{fb-rt|ARG|alt}} |score = 1–0 |report= [https://web.archive.org/web/20120827115244/http://www.fifa.com/worldcup/archive/edition%3D21/results/matches/match%3D1447/report.html Report] |team2 = {{fb|BUL|1946}} |goals1 = [[Héctor Facundo|Facundo]] {{goal|4}} |stadium = El Teniente, [[Rancagua]] |attendance = 7,134 |referee = Juan Gardeazábal Garay ([[Royal Spanish Football Federation|Spain]]) }} ---- {{Football box |date = 31 {{goal|17}}

[[Lajos Tichy|Tichy]] {{goal|8||70}}
[[Ernő Solymosi|Solymosi]] {{goal|12}} |goals2 = [[Georgi Sokolov|Sokolov]] {{goal|64}}RSSSF credits this goal to [[Georgi Asparuhov]]. |stadium = El Teniente, [[Rancagua]] |attendance = 7,442 |referee = Juan Gardeazábal Garay ([[Royal Spanish Football Federation|Spain]]) }} ---- {{Football box |date = 6 June 1962 |time = 15:00 [[Time in Chile|CLT]] ([[UTC-04]]) |team1 = {{fb-rt|HUN}} |score = 0–0 |report= [https://web.archive.org/web/20120919020752/http://www.fifa.com/worldcup/archive/edition%3D21/results/matches/match%3D1451/report.html Report] |team2 = {{fb|ARG|alt}} |stadium = El Teniente, [[Rancagua]] |attendance = 7,945 |referee = Arturo Yamasaki Maldonado ([[Federación Peruana de Fútbol|Peru]]) }} ---- {{Football box |date = 7 June 1962 |time = 15:00 [[Time in Chile|CLT]] ([[UTC-04]]) |team1 = {{fb-rt|ENG}} |score = 0–0 |report= [https://web.archive.org/web/20100615224508/http://www.fifa.com/worldcup/archive/edition%3D21/results/matches/match%3D1464/report.html Report] |team2 = {{fb|BUL|1946}} |stadium = Estadio El Teniente, [[Rancagua]] |attendance = 5,700 |referee = Antoine Blavier ([[Royal Belgian Football Association|Belgium]]) }} ====Quarter-finals==== {{Football box |date = 10 June 1962 |time = 14:30 [[Time in Chile|CLT]] ([[UTC-04]]) |team1 = {{fb-rt|TCH}} |score = 1–0 |report= [https://web.archive.org/web/20120902062516/http://www.fifa.com/worldcup/archive/edition%3D21/results/matches/match%3D1525/report.html Report] |team2 = {{fb|HUN}} |goals1 = [[Adolf Scherer|Scherer]] {{goal|13}} |stadium = El Teniente, [[Rancagua]] |attendance = 11,690 |referee = [[Nikolay Latyshev]] ([[Football Federation of USSR|Soviet Union]]) }} ==Chile national football team matches== The Estadio El Teniente has hosted three games of the [[Chile national football team]], against [[New Zealand]] in 2006, [[Guatemala]] in 2008, and the [[United States]] in 2015. Before the [[2015 Copa América]], Chile played a friendly match against [[El Salvador]].{{cite web|url=http://www.ohigginsfc.cl/2015/05/20/el-teniente-albergara-ultimo-amistoso-de-chile-antes-de-la-copa-america/|title=El Teniente albergará último amistoso de Chile antes de la Copa América – O'Higgins FC|work=ohigginsfc.cl}} {{Football box |date = 24 April 2006 |time = 21:30 [[Time in Chile|CLT]] ([[UTC-04]]) |team1 = {{fb-rt|CHI}} |score = 4–1 |report= [https://int.soccerway.com/matches/2006/04/25/world/friendlies/chile/new-zealand/361593/head2head/ Report] |team2 = {{fb|NZL}} |goals1 = [[Humberto Suazo|Suazo]] {{goal|36}}
[[Jeremy Christie|Christie]] {{goal|39|o.g.}}
[[Sebastián Roco|Roco]] {{goal|61}}

[[Jozy Altidore|Altidore]] {{goal|31}} |stadium = El Teniente, [[Rancagua]] |attendance = 12,420 |referee = Patricio Loustau ([[Argentine Football Association|Argentina]]) }} ---- {{Football box |date = 5 June 2015 |time = 19:00 [[Time in Chile|CLT]] ([[UTC-04]]) |team1 = {{fb-rt|CHI}} |score = 1–0 |report= [https://int.soccerway.com/matches/2015/06/06/world/friendlies/chile/el-salvador/2033019/ Report] |team2 = {{fb|SLV}} |goals1 = [[Jorge Valdivia|Valdivia]] {{goal|14}} |goals2 = |stadium = El Teniente, [[Rancagua]] |attendance = 12,500 |referee = Fernando Rapallini ([[Argentine Football Association|Argentina]]) }} ==2015 Copa América== {{main article|2015 Copa América}} The fixture schedule was announced on 11 November 2014, and two games were played in the Estadio El Teniente for the [[2015 Copa América]], playing here 4 of 12 countries of the tournament. Both matches were part of the group stage. Teams which played in this stadium for the [[2015 Copa América]]: * {{fb|COL}} * {{fb|VEN}} * {{fb|MEX}} * {{fb|ECU}} ===Group Stage=== {{Football box | date = {{Start date|2015|6|14|df=y}} | time = 16:00 [[Time in Chile|CLT]] ([[UTC-04]]) | team1 = {{fb-rt|COL}} | team2 = {{fb|VEN}} | score = 0–1 | round = Group C | goals1 = | goals2 = [[José Salomón Rondón|Rondón]] {{goal|60}} | stadium = El Teniente, [[Rancagua]] | attendance = 12,387 | referee = [[Andrés Cunha]] ([[Uruguayan Football Association|Uruguay]]) | report = [http://estadisticas.conmebol.com/html/v3/index.html?channel=deportes.futbol.copaamerica.215730&lang=es_LA&theme=copaamerica Report] }} ---- {{Football box | date = {{Start date|2015|6|19|df=y}} | time = 18:00 [[Time in Chile|CLT]] ([[UTC-04]]) | team1 = {{fb-rt|MEX}} | team2 = {{fb|ECU}} | score = 1–2 | round = Group A | goals1 = [[Raúl Jiménez|Jiménez]] {{goal|63|pen.}} | goals2 = [[Miller Bolaños|Bolaños]] {{goal|25}}
[[Enner Valencia|Valencia]] {{goal|57}} | stadium = El Teniente, [[Rancagua]] | attendance = 11,051 | referee = [[José Argote]] ([[Venezuelan Football Federation|Venezuela]]) | report = [http://www.ca2015.com/es/match/preview/1947881 Report] }} ==Attendances== Note: This table only includes attendances since the remodelation of the stadium, that was officially opened on July 2014 in a match against [[Club Universidad de Chile|Universidad de Chile]]. {| class="wikitable" |- ! Season !! Division !! Average attendance !! Highest attendance !! Lowest attendance |- |[[2014–15 Chilean Primera División season|2014–15]]||[[Primera División de Chile|Campeonato Nacional]]||6,150||10,636 v [[Club Universidad de Chile|Universidad de Chile]]{{cite web|url=http://www.capodeprovincia.cl/2014/07/el-capo-tropezo-en-el-teniente.html|title=El Capo tropezó en El Teniente...|work=Capo de Provincia}}||0 v [[Unión La Calera]] {{ref|Renteria|[note]}} {{cite web|url=http://www.capodeprovincia.cl/2015/01/ohiggins-continuo-con-los-abrazos-de.html|title=O'Higgins continuó con los abrazos de año nuevo...|work=Capo de Provincia}} |- |2015–16||[[Primera División de Chile|Campeonato Nacional]]||6,229||13,160 v [[C.D. Universidad de Concepción|Universidad de Concepción]] {{cite web|url=http://www.capodeprovincia.cl/2016/04/nos-volveremos-levantar.html|title=Nos volveremos a levantar...|work=Capo de Provincia}}||3,429 v [[Huachipato]] {{cite web|url=http://www.cdf.cl/cdf/site/edic/base/port/widget.html?season=2015&competition=370&match=818629|title=O'Higgins vs. Huachipato timeline and statistics|work=CDF.cl}} |} : 1.{{note|Renteria}} ANFP punishment to O'Higgins playing without public one home match by the racism acts to [[Emilio Rentería]] in a match on the stadium.{{cite web|url=http://www.emol.com/noticias/deportes/2014/11/27/692023/anfp-castiga-a-ohiggins-con-un-partido-a-puertas-cerradas-por-insusltos-racistas-a-renteria.html|title=ANFP castiga a O'Higgins con un partido a puertas cerradas por insultos racistas a Rentería|work=Emol}} ==Transport connections== ===Bus=== [[:es:Terminal O'Higgins|Terminal O'Higgins]] is the principal bus stop of the city, and the stadium is 1.05 miles (1.7 km) away following the [[Rancagua]] avenues. The [[:es:Tur Bus|Tur Bus]] terminal at Rancagua is 1.55 miles (2.35 km) away of the stadium. Bus lines (''micros'') with a stop close to El Teniente are: [[File:Trans-OHiggins.png]] [[Trans O'Higgins]] lines: * 101, 102 and 103 – Circunvalación * 201, 202, and 203 – Isabel Riquelme * 301, 302, 303 and 304 – Cachapoal * 403 – Manzanal ===Tramway=== The stadium is 1.18 miles (1.9 km) away from the [[Estación Rancagua]] ([[Metrotrén]]). ===Airport=== The city only has the [[:es:Aeródromo de la Independencia|Aeródromo de la Independencia]], but receives only the private jets and [[Chilean Army]] flights. The nearest international airport is the [[Comodoro Arturo Merino Benítez International Airport]], in [[Santiago, Chile|Santiago]]. ==Images== File:ElTeniente20142.jpg| View from Angostura File:Teniente Marquesina.jpg| View of the Marquesina and VIP section File:ElTeniente2014.jpg| View from Angostura to Andes File:ElTeniente20141.jpg| View from Angostura to Rengo File:Estadio_Bicentenario_El_Teniente_%E2%80%94_Rengo.jpg| View from Rengo to Angostura and Marquesina File:Teniente Angostura.jpg| View from Rengo File:El_Teniente_Nuevo_II.jpg| View from Marquesina to Andes File:ElTenienteNuevo.JPG| The stadium on construction ==References== {{commons category}} {{O'Higgins F.C.}} {{1962 FIFA World Cup stadiums}} {{2015 Copa América stadiums}} {{Chilean Primera División Venues}} [[Category:O'Higgins F.C.|El Teniente]] [[Category:Football venues in Chile|El Teniente]] [[Category:1962 FIFA World Cup stadiums]] [[Category:Copa América stadiums|El Teniente]] [[Category:Sports venues in O'Higgins Region]] [[Category:Multi-purpose stadiums in Chile]] [[Category:Rancagua]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1947]]

{{Infobox venue | stadium_name = Estadio Juan Francisco Barraza | previous_name = Estadio Migueleño | nickname = Nido Aguilucho | image = [[Image:Estadio Barraza.jpg|200px]]|| fullname = Estadio Municipal Juan Francisco Barraza | location = [[San Miguel, El Salvador|San Miguel]], [[El Salvador]] | built = 15 November 1956 | renovated = 2016-2017 | closed = | demolished = | owner = Mayor of San Miguel | operator = | surface = Grass | construction_cost = [[U.S. Dollar|$]] 43,558.34 | architect = Paredes Lemus | former_names = | tenants = [[C.D. Águila]]
[[C.D. Dragón]] | seating_capacity = 10,000http://elmundo.sv/presidente-inaugura-remodelacion-del-estadio-juan-francisco-barraza/| }} '''Estadio Juan Francisco Barraza''' is a [[multi-purpose stadium]] in [[San Miguel, El Salvador|San Miguel]], [[El Salvador]].http://www.laprensagrafica.com/2017/05/20/comision-disciplinaria-fesfut-sanciono-al-barraza-con-un-juego It is currently used mostly for [[football (soccer)|football]] matches and is the home stadium of [[C.D. Águila]] and [[C.D. Dragón]]. It is named after the 1950s star [[Juan Francisco Barraza|Juan Francisco "Cariota" Barraza]] in 1982. The stadium holds 10,000 people.http://www.elgrafico.com/2017/05/14/santa-tecla-se-queja-de-las-malas-condiciones-de-camerinos-en-el-barraza ==History== Construction began on November 1956 and was under the direction of Pablo Paredes Lemus and Cia. After 3 years of building, The stadium was opened and held its very first game on November 15, 1959. This day saw Honduran Club Deportivo Olimpia play against Águila and drew 1-1. In 1982, 26 years after its construction, the Aguila board, decided to change its name to Estadio Juan Francisco Barraza, after the iconic footballer in El Salvador. {{coord|13.482576|-88.169038|format=dms|type:landmark_scale:3000|display=title}} {{Salvadoran Primera División venues}} ==References== {{Reflist}} [[Category:Football venues in El Salvador]] [[Category:Multi-purpose stadiums in El Salvador]] {{ElSalvador-sports-venue-stub}}

{{about|the basketball team|other sections of the sports club|Legia Warsaw (sports club)}} {{Infobox basketball club | name = Legia Warszawa | nickname = ''Wojskowi'' ("Militarians"),
''Legioniści'' ("Legionnaires", "Legionarries") | logo = Legia Warszawa basketball logo.png | league = [[Polish Basketball League|PLK]] | image_size = | founded = {{Start date and age|1929}} | history = '''Legia Warsaw'''
1929–present | arena = OSiR Bemowo | capacity= 1,000{{Cite web|url=http://basketball.eurobasket.com/team/Poland/Legia-Warszawa/112|title=Legia Warszawa|publisher=Eurobasket.com|access-date=5 June 2018}} | location = [[Warsaw]], Poland | colors = Red, White, Green and Black
{{color box|red}} {{color box|white}} {{color box|#008f3d}} {{color box|black}} | president = [[:pl:Roman Podobas|Roman Podobas]] | coach = [[:pl:Piotr Bakun|Piotr Bakun]] | website = {{URL|http://legiakosz.com/}} | championships = '''7''' [[Polish Basketball League|Polish Championships]]
'''2''' [[Polish Basketball Cup|Polish Cups]]
'''1''' [[I Liga (basketball)|I Liga]] | h_body=000000|h_pattern_b=_basket_in_white |h_shorts=FFFFFF|h_pattern_s=_blacktop | a_body=008f3d|a_pattern_b=_basket_with_white|a_shorts=008f3d|a_pattern_s= }} '''Sportowy Klub Legia Warszawa''' ({{IPA-pl|ˈlɛɡʲja varˈʂava|lang}}) is a [[Poland|Polish]] men's basketball club, based in [[Warsaw]]. The team currently plays in the [[Polish Basketball League|PLK]], the Polish first division. The club was established in 1929 as the basketball section of the military multi-sport club of [[Legia Warsaw]]. Legia became the leading team in Polish basketball in the 1950s and 1960s with seven national championships and two national cups. In 2017, Legia was promoted to the [[Polish Basketball League|PLK]] after being absent for 14 years.{{Cite news|url=http://eurosport.onet.pl/koszykowka/polska-liga-koszykowki/legia-warszawa-wywalczyla-awans-do-polskiej-ligi-koszykowki/ynxx8m|title=Legia Warszawa wywalczyła awans do Polskiej Ligi Koszykówki|date=2017-05-20|publisher=Eurosport.onet.pl}} ==Honours== :'''Total titles: 9''' ===Domestic competitions=== *'''[[Polish Basketball League|Polish Championship]]:''' **'''Winners (7):''' 1956, 1957, 1960, 1961, 1963, 1966, 1969 *'''[[Polish Cup (basketball)|Polish Cup]]:''' **'''Winners (2):''' 1968, 1970 *'''[[I Liga (basketball)|I Liga]]''' **'''Winners (1):''' 2017 ==Season by season== {| class="wikitable" style="font-size:85%;" !Season !Tier !League !{{Tooltip|Pos.|Position after Playoffs}} !Record ![[Polish Basketball Cup|Polish Cup]] |- |bgcolor=#efefef| 2011–12 |align=center|4 |3 Liga | bgcolor=#BBF3BB align=center|1st | | |- |bgcolor=#efefef| 2012–13 |align=center|3 |2 Liga |align=center|{{Tooltip|3rd|Group C}} | | |- |bgcolor=#efefef| 2013–14 |align=center|3 |2 Liga | bgcolor=#BBF3BB align=center|{{Tooltip|1st|Group A}} | | |- |bgcolor=#efefef| 2014–15 |align=center|2 |[[I Liga (basketball)|I Liga]] | align=center|4th | | |- |bgcolor=#efefef| 2015–16 |align=center|2 |[[I Liga (basketball)|I Liga]] | align=center|2nd | | |- |bgcolor=#efefef| 2016–17 |align=center|2 |[[I Liga (basketball)|I Liga]] | bgcolor=#BBF3BB align=center|1st | | |- |bgcolor=#efefef| [[2017–18 PLK season|2017–18]] |align=center|1 |[[Polish Basketball League|PLK]] |16th |
5–27
|[[2018 Polish Basketball Cup|Quarterfinalist]] |} ==International record== {| class="toccolours" border="0" cellpadding="2" cellspacing="0" align="left" style="margin:0.5em;" |- bgcolor=#CADCFB ! Season ! Achievement ! Notes |- !colspan="4" bgcolor=#EFEFEF | [[Euroleague Basketball|Euroleague]] |- | align="center" | [[1958 FIBA European Champions Cup|1958]] | align="center" | '''Quarter-finals''' | align="left" | eliminated by [[ASK Riga]], 59-93 ('''L''') in [[Riga]] and 63-61 ('''W''') in [[Warsaw]] |- | align="center" | [[1960–61 FIBA European Champions Cup|1960–61]] | align="center" | '''Quarter-finals''' | align="left" | eliminated by [[PBC CSKA Moscow|CSKA Moscow]], 72-98 ('''L''') in [[Warsaw]] and 73-85 ('''L''') in Moscow |- | align="center" | [[1961–62 FIBA European Champions Cup|1961–62]] | align="center" | '''Quarter-finals''' | align="left" | eliminated by [[Real Madrid Baloncesto|Real Madrid]], 73-62 ('''W''') in [[Warsaw]] and 71-100 ('''L''') in [[Madrid]] |- | align="center" | [[1963–64 FIBA European Champions Cup|1963–64]] | align="center" | '''Quarter-finals''' | align="left" | eliminated by [[Real Madrid Baloncesto|Real Madrid]], 90-102 ('''L''') in [[Warsaw]] and 86-92 ('''L''') in [[Madrid]] |- !colspan="4" bgcolor=#EFEFEF | [[FIBA Saporta Cup|Saporta Cup]] |- | align="center" | [[1968–69 FIBA European Cup Winners' Cup|1968–69]] | align="center" | '''Quarter-finals''' | align="left" | eliminated by [[BC Slavia Prague|Slavia Prague]], 82-113 ('''L''') in [[Prague]] and 80-91 ('''L''') in [[Warsaw]] |- | align="center" | [[1970–71 FIBA European Cup Winners' Cup|1970–71]] | align="center" | '''Quarter-finals''' | align="left" | eliminated by [[Fides Napoli]], 75-84 ('''L''') in [[Warsaw]] and 73-96 ('''L''') in [[Napoli]] |} {{clear}} ==Players== ===Notable players=== {{Basketball notable players criteria}} *{{flagicon|POL}} [[Cezary Trybański]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://legiakosz.com/ Official website] {{Polish Basketball League}} {{Legia Warsaw}} [[Category:Legia Warsaw]] [[Category:Basketball teams in Poland]] [[Category:Military sports clubs]] [[Category:1929 establishments in Poland]]

page.title: List of North American football nicknames

revision.text:
This is a list of nicknames in the sports of [[American football]] and [[Canadian football]].
== Players == <!-- per [[WP:BLP]], [[WP:V]], and [[WP:NOR]], please include a <ref name="auto">source</ref> for every nickname--> <!--ALPHABETICAL ORDER--> * "A-Train" – [[Mike Alstott]], [[running back]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://bleacherreport.com/articles/1403423-mike-alstott-the-last-true-fullback-in-nfl-history#articles/1403423-mike-alstott-the-last-true-fullback-in-nfl-history|title=Was Mike Alstott the NFL's Last True FB?|first=Greg |last=Maiola|publisher=}}</ref> * "All Day" – [[Adrian Peterson]], [[running back]]<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/nfl/vikings/2013/10/17/adrian-peterson-attended-sons-funeral-tyrese-robert-ruffin/3003117/|title=Adrian Peterson: Son's death is 'devastating'|date=17 October 2013|work=[[USA Today]]|agency=Associated Press|accessdate=25 November 2013}}</ref> * "The Assassin" - [[Jack Tatum]], Oakland Raiders, safety * "Avatar" – [[Jimmy Graham]], [[tight end]]<ref>{{cite news|title=Jimmy Graham Talks Drew Brees' Nickname for him, Rob Gronkowski and More from Super Bowl Week|url=http://www.canalstreetchronicles.com/2013/2/1/3940350/saints-jimmy-graham-drew-brees-nickname-rob-gronkowski-super-bowl|publisher=canalstreetchronicles.com|date=February 1, 2013}}</ref> * "Bad Moon" - [[Andre Rison]], many teams, wide receiver * "Baggadonuts" - [[Frank Winters]], [[Green Bay Packers]], center * "The Bearded Pony" - [[Andrew Luck]], [[Indianapolis Colts]], named for his amazing beard and the fact that he plays for the Colts. * "Beast Mode" – [[Marshawn Lynch]], [[Seattle Seahawks]], named for his violent running style and unusual ability to break tackles <ref>{{cite news| url=http://blog.seattlepi.com/football/2012/11/14/marshawn-lynch-and-the-evolution-of-beast-mode | work=Seattle Post-Intelligencer | title=Marshawn Lynch and the evolution of 'Beast Mode'}}</ref> * "Big Phil" - [[Phil Loadholt]], Minnesota Vikings offensive tackle<ref>{{cite news|last1=Burnfin|first1=J. Levi|title=Buster history mural the highlight of DPAC renovation|url=http://www.gctelegram.com/sports/buster-history-mural-the-highlight-of-dpac-renovation/article_8c5ebdfd-1168-529b-ae9b-e582869cfa79.html|work=Garden City Telegram}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Wobschall|first1=Mike|title=Thank You, Big Phil|url=http://www.vikings.com/news/article-1/Thank-You-Big-Phil/bb60d219-dba0-4996-a813-ec46e55a564f|website=vikings.com|date=July 26, 2016}}</ref> * "Blood" - [[John McNally (American football)|John McNally]], [[Green Bay Packers]], running back * "Boob" - [[Boob Darling|Bernard Darling]], [[Green Bay Packers]], center * "Broadway Joe" - [[Joe Namath]], New York Jets, quarterback * "Buckets" - [[Charles Goldenberg]], [[Green Bay Packers]], guard/running back * "The Bus" - [[Jerome Bettis]], [[Pittsburgh Steelers]], running back * "Captain Comeback" - [[Roger Staubach]], Dallas Cowboys, quarterback * "The Claymaker" – [[Clay Matthews III]]<ref>{{cite news|title=Clay Matthews: The Predator|url=http://www.bodybuilding.com/fun/clay-matthews-the-predator.html|publisher=Bodybuilder.com|date=May 10, 2012}}</ref> * "Cool Brees" – [[Drew Brees]]<ref>{{cite news|title=Purdue Graduation Briefs — Brees throws touchdowns in game of life|url=http://www.purdue.edu/uns/html3month/2001/010427.Graduation.briefs.html|publisher=[[Purdue University]]|date=April 27, 2001}}</ref> * "The Cowboy" – [[Justin Smith (defensive end)|Justin Smith]]<ref>{{cite web | url=http://espn.go.com/nfl/playoffs/2012/story/_/id/8894385/super-bowl-xlvii-justin-smith-just-does-job | title=Justin Smith just does his job | accessdate=18 January 2014}}</ref> * "Curly" - [[Curly Lambeau|Earl Louis Lambeau]], [[Green Bay Packers]], founder, halfback and coach * "Danimal" – [[Dan Hampton]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.profootballhof.com/hof/member.aspx?player_id=87|title=Dan Hampton Bio - Pro Football Hall of Fame Official Site|publisher=}}</ref> * "Deacon" - [[Deacon Jones|David Jones]], Los Angeles Rams, defensive end * "The Diesel" - [[John Riggins]], Washington Redskins, running back * "[[Dirty Dozen (American football)|Dirty Dozen]]" = [[1975 NFL season|1975]] [[Dallas Cowboys]] team * * "The Dodger" – [[Roger Staubach]], [[quarterback]] * "The Dome Patrol" – the New Orleans Saints football team's [[Linebacker (American football)|linebacker]] corps of the late 1980s and the early 1990s. [[Jerry Rice]], San Francisco 49ers, wide receiver
== Teams == This is a list of nicknames of professional and college football teams. Many are merely abbreviations or diminutives of the team's name; otherwise, the origin of the nickname (if known) is noted. An [[asterisk]] [[asterisk|(*)]] after a nickname indicates that the name is pejorative, insulting, or has at least a negative intent, and is often used by opponents or detractors (including fans when the team is performing poorly). Note on abbreviations: CFL – [[Canadian Football League]]; NFL – [[National Football League]]; NCAA – [[National Collegiate Athletic Association]]
=== American football === <!-- per [[WP:V]] and [[WP:NOR]], please include a <ref name="auto"/> for every nickname--> '''By nickname''' * "Ain'ts*" – '''[[New Orleans Saints]]''', NFL; rhyming play on the non-standard [[English language|English]] negative [[ain't]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sportingnews.com/yourturn/viewtopic.php?p=254364|title=Sporting News - NFL - NCAA - NBA - MLB - NASCAR - UFC - WWE|publisher=|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071002020015/http://www.sportingnews.com/yourturn/viewtopic.php?p=254364|archivedate=2007-10-02|df=}}</ref> * "America's Team" – '''[[Dallas Cowboys]]''', by sports media<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/dp/B0000C8AO2|title=NFL Films - The Dallas Cowboys - The Complete History|date=25 November 2003|publisher=|via=Amazon}}</ref> * "B.I.L.L.S.*" – '''[[Buffalo Bills]]''', by detractors, acronyms for "'''B'''oy '''I''' '''L'''ove '''L'''osing [[Super Bowl|'''S'''uper Bowl]]s", in reference to the team's failure to win the Super Bowl in four straight tries during the early 1990s<ref>{{cite web|url=http://out-route.gloriousnoise.com/2006/08/shattering_the_culture_of_losing.php|title=The Out Route - Shattering The Cbrushers baked beans murluulture of Losing|accessdate=2006-11-15}}</ref> * "[[Big Blue Wrecking Crew|Big Blue (Wrecking Crew)]]" – '''[[New York Giants]]''', NFL; from the color of their jerseys, influenced by the nickname of [[IBM]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bigblueinteractive.com/|title=BigBlueInteractive - New York Giants News and Discussion|publisher=}}</ref> * "The Black and Gold" – '''[[Pittsburgh Steelers]]''', NFL; from their uniform colors<ref>[http://www.blackandgoldbrigade.com/ Welcome To The Black and Gold Brigade!<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> * "Black and Blue Division" – '''[[NFC North]]''', NFL; from the division's rugged style of play in the 20th century (also "Frostbite Division") * "The Blue Giants" – Used for '''[[New York Giants]]''' because of the team color * "Bolts" – '''[[Los Angeles Chargers]]''', NFL; from the [[Thunderbolt|lightning bolt]] design on their helmets<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chargers.com/team/history/index.html|title=History|date=8 July 2014|publisher=}}</ref> * "Bucs/Buckies" – '''[[Tampa Bay Buccaneers]]''', NFL; abbreviation of team name * "The Bungles" – '''[[Cincinnati Bengals]]''', NFL; formerly used by detractors<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.altoonamirror.com/page/content.detail/id/556002/Cincinnati-looks-like-same-old--Bungles-.html?nav=818|title=Cincinnati looks like same old ‘Bungles’|last=Mehno|first=John|date=5 December 2011|work=Altoona Mirror|accessdate=25 November 2013}}</ref> * The Cardiac Cats – '''[[Carolina Panthers]]''', coined in 2003 due to their frequent 4th-quarter comebacks and/or losses * "[[Cheeseheads]]" – Nickname used for residents of Wisconsin in reference to the state's large dairy industry. Sometimes employed derogatorily by neighboring states, the moniker was embraced by residents, particularly Green Bay Packers fans, and has become synonymous with Wisconsin's football culture. (While the state is presently known for cheese production, the Packers team itself was originally named for the Indian meat packing company in Green Bay, WI.)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.packers.com/history/birth-of-a-team-and-a-legend.html|title=Packers.com - Birth of a Team & a Legend|publisher=|access-date=2011-01-31|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140218235758/http://www.packers.com/history/birth-of-a-team-and-a-legend.html|archive-date=2014-02-18|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> * "Cheatriots" -'''[[New England Patriots]]''',NFL; Used by detractors as a reference to the Patriots cheating allegations during Bill Belichick and Tom Brady era * "The Chefs" – '''[[Kansas City Chiefs]]''', NFL; origin [[Snickers]] candy bar commercial; however, the NFL has licensed official "Kansas City Chief Head Chef Cookie Jars"<ref>[http://mvp.com/sm-memory-company-kansas-city-chiefs-cookie-jar--pi-2105066.html CBSSportsStore.com - Memory Company Kansas City Chiefs Cookie Jar<!-- Bot generated title -->]{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> * "The Chesapeake Watershed Region Indigenous Persons" – '''[[Washington Redskins]]''', NFL; translation of team name into [[political correctness|politically correct terms]]<ref name=autogenerated2>{{cite web |url=http://www.nfl.com/nflnetwork/story/7630560 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2006-01-15 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060104110345/http://www.nfl.com/nflnetwork/story/7630560 |archivedate=2006-01-04 |df= }}</ref> It was later changed to "Potomac Drainage Basin Indigenous Persons" (see below) since the [[Baltimore Ravens]] also share the [[Chesapeake Bay]] region. * "Clowns" - '''[[Cleveland Browns]]''', NFL; used by detractors. * The Cowgirls - '''[[Dallas Cowboys]]''', by detractors. * "Da Raidahs" – '''[[Oakland Raiders]]''', NFL; The way [[Chris Berman]] of ESPN says, "The Raiders",<ref>[http://thebwp.com/wire/DA.cfm?ArticleID=1038 This N' That with Tony Mack:NFL Picks: Week 11<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20041114123857/http://www.thebwp.com/wire/DA.cfm?ArticleID=1038 |date=2004-11-14 }}</ref> a spoof of Raiders team owner [[Al Davis]]' accent. * "Dawgs" – '''[[Cleveland Browns]]''', NFL; according to [[Hanford Dixon]], then a [[cornerback]] with the original Art Modell-owned Browns, he gave his defensive teammates this nickname to inspire them before the 1985 season<ref>http://66.181.85.108/news_room/history/arts/1180.0.html{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> * "DeadSkins" – '''[[Washington Redskins]]''', NFL; rhyming play on team name; used by detractors or disgruntled fans.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tpmcafe.com/story/2005/11/20/163558/96 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2006-01-15 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20051129033240/http://www.tpmcafe.com/story/2005/11/20/163558/96 |archivedate=2005-11-29 |df= }}</ref> * "Detroit Lie-downs" – '''[[Detroit Lions]]''', NFL; so called because they just lie down and let other teams run over them. * "The Dirty Birds" – '''[[Atlanta Falcons]]''', NFL; team dubbed themselves by this name during their race to [[Super Bowl XXXIII]]<ref>[http://www.atlantafalcons.com/history/1990s.jsp Atlanta Falcons | Media Lounge | We're Sorry<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060505153614/http://www.atlantafalcons.com/history/1990s.jsp |date=2006-05-05 }}</ref> * "The Dolts" – '''[[Indianapolis Colts]]''', NFL; rhyming play on name with a term for "idiot"; by detractors<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sportsnote.com/this&that/99_4-19_mike27.htm|title=sportsnote.com - This website is for sale! - sportsnote Resources and Information.|publisher=}}</ref> * "The Donks" - '''[[Denver Broncos]]''', used by detractors. * "[[Galactic Empire (Star Wars)|The Empire]]" - Used by detractors to refer to either the '''[[Dallas Cowboys]]''', due to their reputation of having a large fanbase, lots of money, and several Super Bowl rings, and the '''[[New England Patriots]]''', due to their own reputation of also being one of the most hated teams in the NFL and being the de facto villain for the league, and because of their recent Super Bowl dynasty. The "role" of [[Palpatine|the Emperor]] is usually filled by [[Jerry Jones]] or [[Bill Belichick]]. * "The Flaming Thumbtacks" – '''[[Tennessee Titans]]''', NFL; a humorous interpretation of their team logo, actually a flaming stylized letter "T"<ref>[http://pittsburghdish.typepad.com/pittsburgh_dish/2005/09/bra_rah_rah_the.html Pittsburgh Dish: Bra Rah Rah: The Flaming Thumbtacks<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060627032638/http://pittsburghdish.typepad.com/pittsburgh_dish/2005/09/bra_rah_rah_the.html |date=2006-06-27 }}</ref> * "The Fins" – '''[[Miami Dolphins]]''', NFL; play on abbreviation of name with the appendages of a dolphin<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.sun-sentinel.com/sports_football_dolphins/2005/10/friday_night_fo.html|title=Miami Dolphins - Sun-Sentinel Blogs: Friday night football?<!-- Bot generated title -->|publisher=|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20051108165007/http://blogs.sun-sentinel.com/sports_football_dolphins/2005/10/friday_night_fo.html|archivedate=2005-11-08|df=}}</ref> * "The Fish" – '''[[Miami Dolphins]]''', NFL; while the [[mascot]] and [[team logo]] of [[bottlenose dolphins]] are not [[fish]], but [[mammal]]s. The rhyme detractors used when they played in the [[Miami Orange Bowl|Orange Bowl]] was, "squish the fish in the Orange Dish." Now rarely used due to the [[Florida Marlins]], who are also called "The Fish". * "The Forty-Whiners/The Whiners" - '''[[San Francisco 49ers]]''', used by detractors. * "G-Men" – '''[[New York Giants]]''', NFL; initial of team name, possibly a play on the term for a government (e.g., [[FBI]]) agent<ref>[http://www.thewbalchannel.com/nfl079/5822677/detail.html G-Men Have Carolina In Their Mind - NFL - New York Giants News Story - WBAL Baltimore<!-- Bot generated title -->]{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> * "Goats" – '''[[Los Angeles Rams]]''', NFL; when playing poorly<ref name=autogenerated1>[http://insidepulse.com/article.php?contentid=28419 Tailgate Crashers: Second And Long - 10.27.04<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060107042507/http://www.insidepulse.com/article.php?contentid=28419 |date=2006-01-07 }}</ref> * "Iggles" – '''[[Philadelphia Eagles]]''', NFL; reference to how some Philadelphians pronounce "Eagles"<ref name="McCarthy2012">{{cite book|last=McCarthy|first=Iris|title=Food Lovers' Guide to Philadelphia: The Best Restaurants, Markets & Local Culinary Offerings|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=TKkROvfuWoQC&pg=PA9|accessdate=25 November 2013|date=2012-09-18|publisher=Globe Pequot|isbn=9780762788965|page=9}}</ref> * "Jags" – '''[[Jacksonville Jaguars]]''', NFL; abbreviation of team name * "Gang Green" – '''[[New York Jets]]''', NFL; used by supporters (reference to medical condition that is difficult to overcome)(Green Bay Packers), NFL; used by supporters since the mid-1970s; also the name of the unofficial team mascot who is given home field credentials. * "Jest" – '''[[New York Jets]]''', NFL; humorous misspelling of team name; used when team is performing poorly<ref> [http://www.newyorkjest.com/ New Page 2<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> * "Jints" – '''[[New York Giants]]''', NFL; used occasionally by local media, as [[eye dialect]] for the team's name. Also used for the baseball team while it was in New York. * "Jokeland (Faders/Traitors)"* – '''[[Oakland Raiders]]''', by detractors<ref name=autogenerated1 /> * "Lambs" – '''[[Los Angeles Rams]]''', NFL; a lamb being a soft, cuddly, meek baby sheep (as opposed to a ram, being an aggressive full-grown male sheep); rhyming nickname used by detractors when team performs poorly<ref>[http://www.fantasyinfocentral.com/football/predictions/004379.php MAC Attack! | Out on a Limb: Fantasy Football Predictions - Fantasy Information Central<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060319201211/http://www.fantasyinfocentral.com/football/predictions/004379.php |date=2006-03-19 }}</ref> * "[[Monsters of the Midway]]" – '''[[Chicago Bears]]''', NFL; originally applied to the [[University of Chicago]] "Maroons", a strong (former) college football team; "Midway" refers to the [[Midway Plaisance]], a long, green swath of boulevard space bordering the southern end of the campus. The University discontinued its football program in 1939, and the Bears adopted the nickname.<ref>{{cite web|title=Monsters of the Midway|url=http://www.chicagobears.com/monstersofthemidway.asp|work=chicagobears.com}}</ref> * "'Niners" – '''[[San Francisco 49ers]]''', NFL; abbreviation of team name * "The Oilers" – '''[[Tennessee Titans]]''', NFL; a reference of the team's name before it moved to Tennessee, the [[Houston Oilers]] * "The Tennessee Titanics"* – NFL, reference given to the team after their 0–6 start in 2009 including a 59–0 loss to the Patriots, this after going 13–3 in 2008 * "The Pack" – '''[[Green Bay Packers]]''', NFL; abbreviation of name, and a play on the collective term for a group of animals such as dogs or wolves<ref>[http://www.edmontonsun.com/Sports/Football/2006/01/13/1392094-sun.html edmontonsun.com - Football - New leader of the Pack<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> * "Pats" – '''[[New England Patriots]]''', NFL; abbreviation of team name * "The Patsies" – '''[[New England Patriots]]''', NFL; play on nickname "Pats" (above) and the term ''[http://www.webster.com/cgi-bin/dictionary?sourceid=Mozilla-search&va=patsy patsy]'', "a person who is easily manipulated or victimized"<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.time.com/time/archive/preview/0,10987,946720,00.html|work=Time|title=Sport: New England: Patsies No More|date=1976-10-18|accessdate=2010-05-08}}</ref> * "The Potomac Drainage Basin Indigenous Persons" – '''[[Washington Redskins]]''', NFL; translation of team name into [[political correctness|politically correct terms]],<ref name=autogenerated2 /> popularized by NFL columnist and [[Washington, D.C.]] resident [[Gregg Easterbrook]] in his weekly column ''Tuesday Morning Quarterback''. * "Seagulls" – '''[[Seattle Seahawks]]''', term often said by detractors when Seahawks are playing poorly.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.spreadshirt.com/us/US/Go-Seagulls-/Designs-63/Marketplace/Designs/detail/design/901157|title=Overview - Customized t shirts and hats : Spreadshirt|first=|last=Spreadshirt|publisher=}}</ref> * "The Silver and Black" – '''[[Oakland Raiders]]''', NFL; from the colors of the uniforms<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.silverandblackattack.com/|title=Silverandblackattack.com|publisher=}}</ref> * "Silver Rush" – '''[[Detroit Lions]]''' * "Sinners" – '''[[New Orleans Saints]]''', NFL; "sinner" is often a paired opposite of "saint"; used by detractors,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dustbury.com/archives/001666.html|title=dustbury.com: Not to mention the New Orleans Sinners|publisher=}}</ref> but also as a result of [[New Orleans Saints bounty scandal|New Orleans Saints Bounty Scandal]] * "'Skins" – '''[[Washington Redskins]]''', NFL; abbreviation of team name * "'Stillers" – '''[[Pittsburgh Steelers]]''', NFL; how native Pittsburghers (Picksbergers) pronounce the name of their team<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pittsburghese.com/glossary.ep.html?type=sports|title=Pittsburghese: sports|publisher=}}</ref> * "Tennessee Traitors " * – '''[[Tennessee Titans]]''', NFL; derisive nickname of the former Houston Oilers, usually aimed at owner Bud Adams by former Oilers fans * "Vikes" – '''[[Minnesota Vikings]]''', NFL; abbreviation of team name<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sportingnews.com/yourturn/viewtopic.php?t=52730|title=Sporting News - NFL - NCAA - NBA - MLB - NASCAR - UFC - WWE|publisher=|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071002114402/http://www.sportingnews.com/yourturn/viewtopic.php?t=52730|archivedate=2007-10-02|df=}}</ref>
=== Canadian football === * "Als" – '''[[Montreal Alouettes]]''', CFL; abbreviation of name * "Argos" – '''[[Toronto Argonauts]]''', CFL; abbreviation of name * "The Blue and Gold" – '''[[Winnipeg Blue Bombers]]''', CFL; after the team colours * "The Boatmen" – '''[[Toronto Argonauts]]''', CFL; in reference to the team's foundation by the [[Argonaut Rowing Club]] of Toronto, which in turn was derived from [[Jason]] and the [[Argonauts]], mythical heroes and boatmen who are the namesake of both the rowing club and the CFL team * "Bombers" – '''[[Winnipeg Blue Bombers]]''', CFL; abbreviation of team name * "The Double Blue" – '''[[Toronto Argonauts]]''', CFL; in reference to the team colours, [[Oxford blue]] and [[Cambridge blue]] * "Esks" or "Eskies" – '''[[Edmonton Eskimos]]''', CFL; abbreviation of team name * "'Gades" – '''[[Ottawa Renegades]]''', CFL; abbreviation of team name * "Jolly Green Giants" – '''[[Saskatchewan Roughriders]]''' for the colour of the team's uniforms and size of the players * "Leos" – '''[[BC Lions]]''', CFL; "Leo" is a common nickname for "lion" (from [[Latin language|Latin]], ''leo'') * "Roughies or Green Riders" – '''[[Saskatchewan Roughriders]]''', CFL; Green Riders to differentiate team from the now defunct Ottawa team of the same name. Roughies - abbreviation of team name * "Stamps" – '''[[Calgary Stampeders]]''', CFL; abbreviation of team name * "Tabbies" - '''[[Hamilton Tiger-Cats]]''' Tabby is a type of domestic cat with stripes * "Ti-cats" – '''[[Hamilton Tiger-Cats]]''', CFL; telescoping of team name
== See also == {{portal|Lists}} * [[Nickname]] * [[List of NFL nicknames]] * [[List of baseball nicknames]] * [[List of basketball nicknames]] * [[List of hockey nicknames]] * [[List of athletes by nickname]] * [[Lists of nicknames]] – nickname list articles on Wikipedia * [[American football]] * [[Canadian football]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = [[James Lynah]] Rink| nickname = | image = | location = [[Cornell University]]
[[Ithaca, NY]]| broke_ground = June 5, 1956| opened = March 21, 1957| expanded = 2007| closed = | demolished = | owner = [[Cornell University]]| operator = [[Cornell University]]| surface = 200x85 [[foot (length)|ft]] (hockey)| construction_cost= | architect = Von Storch, Evans & Burkavage | former_names = | tenants = [[Cornell Big Red]] Men's and Women's Ice Hockey | seating_capacity = 4,267 (hockey) }} '''Lynah Rink''' (pronounced LIE-nuh) is a 4,267-seat hockey [[arena]] at [[Cornell University]] in [[Ithaca, New York]], that opened in 1957. Named after [[James Lynah]], Class of 1905, who was the director of Cornell athletics from 1935 to 1943, it is home to the [[Cornell Big Red|Big Red]] men's and women's [[ice hockey]] teams.{{cite web | last = | first = | title = James Lynah Rink | publisher = Cornell University | date = 2001–02 | url = http://bigred2.athletics.cornell.edu/lynah/history.htm | accessdate = 2006-04-30 }} Lynah has been home to hockey greats such as [[Ken Dryden]], [[Joe Nieuwendyk]], [[Matt Moulson]], [[Digit Murphy]], and [[Canada women's national ice hockey team|Olympic Gold Medalists]] [[Rebecca Johnston]] and [[Brianne Jenner]]. ==History== [[Image:LynahRinkRennovation.jpg|thumb|200px|left|Lynah under renovation, July 2006]] [[Image:Cornell'sawesomehockeyteam.jpg|thumb|left|200px|The Lynah salute]] The building is a [[quonset hut|quonset]] shaped structure covered with multi-colored (orange, tan, black, and brown) brick wall cladding set in a common bond pattern. Projecting from the facade of the structure is a one story rectangular wing flanked on either side by two vertical appendages, which have multi-paned colored glass windows. The one story wing has a strip of [[casement window]]s. The stairway is situated on the west side of the building. A white concrete block structure with wall buttresses connects Lynah Rink to Bartels Hall.{{cite web | last = | first = | title = LYNAH RINK Facility Information | publisher = Cornell University | year = 2006 | url = http://www.fs.cornell.edu/fs/facinfo/fs_facilInfo.cfm?facil_cd=2613 | accessdate = 2006-09-05 }} It was constructed for $500,000 with a donation from [[Walter S. Carpenter, Jr.]] whose gift came with the stipulation that he did not want his name on the building. The facility was designed by Van Storch, Evans, and Burkavage of [[Waverly, PA]] and constructed by Streeter Associates of [[Elmira, NY]]. {{cite book | last = Wodon | first = Adam |author2=Arthur Mintz | title = Cornell University Hockey | publisher = Arcadia Publishing | date = September 1, 2004 | isbn = 0-7385-3672-5 | page = 21 }} The rink opened on March 21, 1957 with a match between the [[New York Rangers]] ([[NHL]]) and the [[Rochester Americans]] ([[American Hockey League|AHL]]) in front of 4200 spectators. It was subsequently dedicated on April 6, 1957 and named the [[James Lynah]] Skating Hall. {{cite book | last = Wodon | first = Adam |author2=Arthur Mintz | title = Cornell University Hockey | publisher = Arcadia Publishing | date = September 1, 2004 | pages = 19–20 | isbn = 0-7385-3672-5 }} In March, 2006 Cornell University broke ground on a major renovation project designed to add {{convert|19500|sqft|m2}} to the rink. The additions and renovations included 464 new seats, upgraded locker rooms for both the men's and women's squads and their opponents, trainers' rooms, coaches' offices and a study area for players. A new scoreboard was added as well as preferred seating and a tunnel for the players. {{cite web | last = Perlin | first = Josh | title = Men's Hockey Reloads Roster | publisher = Cornell Daily Sun | date = 2006-08-21 | url = http://www.cstv.com/sports/m-hockey/uwire/082106aaa.html | accessdate = 2006-09-05 }} ==Lynah Faithful== Fans of Cornell's Hockey program, aptly named the "Lynah Faithful," are among the loudest and most dedicated fans in the country, making Lynah Rink, many believe, one of college hockey's most hostile arenas. The raucous crowd support gives the Big Red one of the largest home ice advantages in college hockey, losing under 20% of their games on home ice since Lynah opened in 1957.http://espn.go.com/espn/thelife/news/story?id=4796116 The Lynah Faithful are cheered on by one cowbell, usually played by a zealous undergraduate,{{cite book | last = Wodon | first = Adam |author2=Arthur Mintz | title = Cornell University Hockey | publisher = Arcadia Publishing | date = September 1, 2004 | pages = | isbn = 0-7385-3672-5 }} but only during the second and third periods (including overtime) at approximately mid-period. Many of the other regular chants of the Faithful are listed on a website, which serves as a useful primer in the history and traditions of Cornell Hockey when initiating new students into the Lynah Faithful.http://www.elynah.com After the end of all games at Lynah, when the opposing team leaves the ice, the Cornell team gathers at center ice and raises their sticks to salute the faithful as they applaud the team. This is known as the '''Lynah salute'''. [[File:LynahCowbellPhoto.jpg|thumb|A zealous undergraduate student plays the cowbell. Chants are generally very loud, and students are known to lose their voices by the end of the match.]] Cornell's men's team has had great success at Lynah Rink, closing in on its 500th win on home ice. Its record at Lynah was 15-0-1 during the 2004–05 season, 15-0-0 during the 2002–03 season, and 14-1-1 during the 2001–02 season. Postseason success at Lynah has been equally impressive. Since Lynah Rink hosted its first postseason game in 1966, Cornell's men's team has a postseason record of 38-7-2 in games played there. During the same period they were 14-1 in single elimination games with the sole loss coming against Providence in 1978 and 12-3 in multi-game series.{{cite web | title = Cornell Postseason Games | publisher = The Big Red What | url = http://www.tbrw.info | accessdate = 2006-09-22 }} Cornell has long been criticized for its policies regarding the distribution of season tickets to men's hockey home games. Students often wait in line for nights to get tickets; however, some believe that this is part of the experience of being among Lynah Faithful. It's common to see students wearing [[T-shirt]]s proudly announcing, "I did my time in the line." In 2005, despite efforts to improve the process over previous years, Cornell was [https://web.archive.org/web/20110607054511/http://www.cornellsun.com/node/15383 criticized] for creating chaos when the Athletic Department announced where students had to go for tickets. In 2006, this was alleviated when the ticket line was preselected at random. During the 2009–10 Hockey season, students did not have to wait in line for season passes given growing concerns over swine flu. Instead the tickets were distributed via a lottery. Beginning in the fall of 2010, Cornell Athletics began distributing tickets via online ticket sales, giving priority to students who had previously purchased season tickets.http://www.cornellbigred.com/news/2010/9/12/MICE_0912100342.aspx[[File:Swanee River, cornell univ pep band, lynah rink.jpg|thumb|right|200px|The Cornell [[Cornell Big Red Pep Band|Pep Band]] [[Sousaphone]]s play [[Old Folks at Home|Swanee River]] over an opposing team's bench to taunt them]] ==See also== *[[Cornell–Harvard hockey rivalry]] *[[Cornell Big Red]] ==References== {{Commons|Category:Lynah Rink}} ==External links== *[http://www.cornellbigred.com/Sports/general/2007/LynahRink.asp Cornell Big Red: Lynah Rink] *[http://www.cornellbigred.com/index.asp?path=mhockey&tab=mens Cornell Men's Team Homepage] *[http://www.cornellbigred.com/index.asp?path=whockey&tab=womens Cornell Women's Team Homepage] *[http://bigred2.athletics.cornell.edu/lynah/ Lynah Rink Page] *[http://lynahrink.com/ Campaign for Big Red Hockey] *[http://lynah.com/ Lynah family history] {{Cornell}} {{ECAC Hockey League}} {{Cornell Big Red men's ice hockey navbox}} {{Cornell Big Red women's ice hockey navbox}} {{coord|42.445783|-76.477435|type:landmark|display=title}} [[Category:Cornell Big Red sports venues]] [[Category:College ice hockey venues in the United States]] [[Category:1957 establishments in New York (state)]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1957]] [[Category:Indoor ice hockey venues in New York (state)]]
