<div id="31_May_2007"> </div id>
==31 May 2007 (Thursday)==
*[[Basketball]]: **[[Florida Gators men's basketball|Florida Gators]] head coach [[Billy Donovan]] has accepted a five-year, $27.5-million contract to become the head coach of the [[Orlando Magic]]. In doing so, he turns down a seven-year extension with unknown terms rumored to range from $3–$3.75m per year from the Gators. [http://www.orlandosentinel.com/sports/basketball/magic/orl-magic0107june01,0,2210050.story?coll=orl-home-headlines (Orlando Sentinel)] [http://sports.espn.go.com/nba/news/story?id=2888555 (ESPN.com)] **[[2007 NBA Playoffs|NBA Playoffs]]: [[Eastern Conference (NBA)|Eastern Conference]] Finals: ***[[Cleveland Cavaliers]] 109, [[Detroit Pistons]] 107, ''2OT'', '''''Cleveland leads series 3–2''''' **:In one of the most-impressive performances in playoff history, [[LeBron James]] scores 29 of the 30 points the Cavs score in the game's last 16 minutes. He finishes with 48 points, including a game-winning layup with 2.2 seconds left in the second overtime to win the game. ([https://sports.yahoo.com/nba/recap?gid=2007053108 AP via Yahoo]) *[[American football]]: **A group of investors, including dot-com billionaire and NBA team owner [[Mark Cuban]], announces that they are exploring the possibility of creating a professional Football league that would compete with the [[National Football League]]. Among the few details are the intention to play on Fridays, and a preliminary designation for the league of "UFL". There are no details on when they would begin play. [http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/news/story?id=2887465 (ESPN.com)] *[[Cricket]]: **[[2007 ICC World Cricket League Division Three]] *** Semifinals ****{{cr|ARG}} 103/6 (34.2 ov.) beat {{cr|CYM}} 102 (39.3 ov.) by 4 wickets ****{{cr|UGA}} 204/9 (49.2 ov.) beat {{cr|PNG}} 203/6 (50 ov.) by 1 wicket *** Plate Semifinals ****{{cr|TZA}} 195 (50 ov.) beat {{cr|FJI}} 127 (48.2 ov.) by 26 runs ****{{cr|ITA}} 146 (45 ov.) beat {{cr|HKG}} 195 (50 ov.) by 49 runs
<div id="30_May_2007"> </div id>
==30 May 2007 (Wednesday)==
*[[Ice hockey]]: **[[2007 Stanley Cup playoffs|Stanley Cup playoffs]]: Stanley Cup Finals: ***[[Anaheim Ducks]] 1, [[Ottawa Senators]] 0. '''''Anaheim leads series 2–0''''' **:[[Samuel Påhlsson]] scores the game's only goal with 5:44 left in regulation. The Senators manage only 16 shots on goal. *[[Basketball]]: **[[2007 NBA Playoffs|NBA Playoffs]]: [[Western Conference (NBA)|Western Conference]] Finals: ***[[San Antonio Spurs]] 109, [[Utah Jazz]] 84, '''''San Antonio wins series 4–1''''' *[[Cricket]]: **[[2007 ICC World Cricket League Division Three]] ***{{cr|PNG}} 135/2 (33.1 ov.) beat {{cr|ITA}} 134/9 (50 ov.) by 8 wickets ***{{cr|ARG}} 46/0 (5 ov.) beat {{cr|FJI}} 44 (21.2 ov.) by 10 wickets ***{{cr|UGA}} 153 (48.3 ov.) beat {{cr|CYM}} 127 (48.2 ov.) by 26 runs ***{{cr|TZA}} 165/5 (46.1 ov.) beat {{cr|HKG}} 161 (47.2) by 5 wickets
<div id="29_May_2007"> </div id>
==29 May 2007 (Tuesday)==
*[[Cricket]]: **[[West Indian cricket team in England in 2007]] ***2nd Test-5th Day: {{cr|West Indies}} vs. {{cr|ENG}} *[[Basketball]]: **[[2007 NBA Playoffs|NBA Playoffs]]: [[Eastern Conference (NBA)|Eastern Conference]] Finals: ***[[Cleveland Cavaliers]] 91, [[Detroit Pistons]] 87, '''''Series tied, 2–2'''''. **:The Cavs overcome another disastrous third quarter thanks to [[LeBron James]], who scores 14 of his 25 points in the final period.
<div id="28_May_2007"> </div id>
==28 May 2007 (Monday)==
*[[Cricket]]: **[[West Indian cricket team in England in 2007]] ***2nd Test-4th Day: {{cr|ENG}} 570/7 ([[declaration and forfeiture|dec]]) beat {{cr|West Indies}} 146 & 141 (42.1 ov.) by an innings and 283 runs. **:This is West Indies's heaviest test defeat. The previous heaviest was an innings and 237 runs. '''''England leads series 1–0''''' **[[2007 ICC World Cricket League Division Three]] ***{{cr|ARG}} 92/5 beat {{cr|PNG}} 91 by 5 wickets ***{{cr|ITA}} 186/9 beat {{cr|FJI}} 149 by 37 runs ***{{cr|UGA}} 70/6 beat {{cr|TZA}} 64 by 4 wickets ***{{cr|CYM}} 70/2 beat {{cr|HKG}} 67 by 8 wickets ***'''''Cayman Islands and Uganda qualify for the Semifinals. Tanzania and Hong Kong are eliminated.''''' *[[Football (soccer)]]: ** [[Football League Championship|English Championship League]] playoff final: *** [[Derby County F.C.|Derby County]] secure the final promotion place to the [[Premier League]] for the [[2007–08 FA Premier League|2007–08 season]] by beating [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]] 1–0. *[[Ice hockey]]: **[[2007 Stanley Cup playoffs|Stanley Cup playoffs]]: Stanley Cup Finals: ***[[Anaheim Ducks]] 3, [[Ottawa Senators]] 2, '''''Anaheim leads series 1–0''''' *[[Basketball]]: **[[2007 NBA Playoffs|NBA Playoffs]]: [[Western Conference (NBA)|Western Conference]] Finals: ***[[San Antonio Spurs]] 91, [[Utah Jazz]] 79, '''''San Antonio leads series 3–1''''' **[[Southeast Asia Basketball Association Championship 2007|Southeast Asia Basketball Association Championship]] at [[Ratchaburi]], [[Thailand]]: ***{{Bk|Philippines}} emerge on the top of the leaderboard as they qualify for the upcoming [[FIBA Asia Championship 2007]] at [[Tokushima, Tokushima|Tokushima]], Japan. {{Bk|Indonesia}}, by virtue of second place, qualifies too. *[[National Football League|NFL]] [[American football|Football]] **[[New England Patriots]] defensive end [[Marquise Hill]] is found dead after a [[personal watercraft]] accident on [[Lake Pontchartrain]] the previous night. A woman that was on his watercraft with him was rescued, but Hill disappeared during the initial rescue attempt. Neither were wearing a [[personal flotation device|life vest]]. The cause of death was ruled an accidental [[drowning]], as drugs and alcohol were not found in his system during his [[autopsy]]. [http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/2007/football/nfl/05/28/bc.fbn.hillsearch.ap/index.html?cnn=yes]
<div id="27_May_2007"> </div id>
==27 May 2007 (Sunday)==
*[[Auto racing]]: **[[2007 Formula One season|Formula One]]: [[2007 Monaco Grand Prix|Monaco Grand Prix]] in [[Circuit de Monaco|Monte Carlo]], [[Monaco]]. *:(1) [[Fernando Alonso]] {{flagicon|ESP}} (2) [[Lewis Hamilton]] {{flagicon|UK}} (3) [[Felipe Massa]] {{flagicon|BRA}} **[[2007 in IRL|IRL]]: The [[2007 Indianapolis 500|Indianapolis 500]] in [[Indianapolis Motor Speedway|Speedway, Indiana]] *:(1) [[Dario Franchitti]] {{flagicon|UK}} (2) [[Scott Dixon]] {{flagicon|NZL}} (3) [[Hélio Castroneves]] {{flagicon|BRA}} **[[2007 in NASCAR Nextel Cup|NASCAR NEXTEL Cup]]: The [[2007 Coca-Cola 600|Coca-Cola 600]] in [[Lowe's Motor Speedway|Concord, North Carolina]] *:(1) [[Casey Mears]] (2) [[J. J. Yeley]] (3) [[Kyle Petty]] *[[Basketball]]: **[[2007 NBA Playoffs|NBA Playoffs]]: [[Eastern Conference (NBA)|Eastern Conference]] Finals: ***[[Cleveland Cavaliers]] 88, [[Detroit Pistons]] 82, '''''Detroit leads series, 2–1'''''. **:[[LeBron James]] scores 32 points, including a late three-pointer that all but ices the game. *[[Cricket]]: **[[Indian cricket team in Bangladesh in 2007]] ***2nd Test-3rd Day: {{cr|IND}} 610/3 ([[declaration and forfeiture|dec]]) beat {{cr|BAN}} 118 & 253 (57.3 ov.) by an innings and 239 runs '''''{{cr|IND}} win series 1–0''''' **[[West Indian cricket team in England in 2007]] ***2nd Test-3rd Day: {{cr|ENG}} 570/7 ([[declaration and forfeiture|dec]]) lead {{cr|West Indies}} 146 & 22/2 (9 ov.) by 402 runs. ''Rain prevented play on Day Three''. **[[2007 ICC World Cricket League Division Three]] ***{{cr|ITA}} 175/9 (50 ov.) beat {{cr|ARG}} 174 (50 ov.) by 1 run ***{{cr|PNG}} 142/9 (49.5 ov.) beat {{cr|FJI}} 138 by 1 wicket ***{{cr|CYM}} 210/0 (45.4 ov.) beat {{cr|TZA}} 206/6 (50 ov.) by 10 wickets ***{{cr|UGA}} 219/5 (50 ov.) beat {{cr|HKG}} 129 (36.5 ov.) by 90 runs **[[International Cricket Council]] president [[Percy Sonn]] dies at age 57 in Cape Town, South Africa after complications from colon cancer. [http://content-usa.cricinfo.com/southafrica/content/current/story/296031.html] *[[Football (soccer)]]: **[[FIFA]] rules that no future international matches may be played at an altitude of over {{convert|2500|m}}. [https://www.fifa.com/aboutfifa/federation/bodies/news/newsid=527696.html (FIFA)]
<div id="26_May_2007"> </div id>
==26 May 2007 (Saturday)==
*[[Lacrosse]]: **The [[Duke Blue Devils|Duke]] lacrosse team beats [[Cornell University|Cornell]], 12–11, to advance to Monday's [[NCAA]] Division I championship. The Blue Devils will play [[Johns Hopkins University|Johns Hopkins]], who defeated [[University of Delaware|Delaware]], 8–3. *[[Mixed martial arts]]: **[[UFC 71]]: [[Quinton Jackson|Quinton "Rampage" Jackson]] defeats [[Chuck Liddell|"The Iceman" Chuck Liddell]] to win the [[Ultimate Fighting Championship]] Light Heavyweight Title by KO (punches) at 1:53 of the first round. *[[Cricket]]: **[[Indian cricket team in Bangladesh in 2007]] ***2nd Test-2nd Day: {{cr|IND}} 610/3 ([[declaration and forfeiture|dec]]) lead {{cr|BAN}} 58/5 (16 ov.) by 552 runs **[[West Indian cricket team in England in 2007]] ***2nd Test-2nd Day: {{cr|ENG}} 570/7 ([[declaration and forfeiture|dec]]) lead {{cr|West Indies}} 146 & 22/2 (9 ov.) by 402 runs *[[Basketball]]: **[[2007 NBA Playoffs|NBA Playoffs]]: [[Western Conference (NBA)|Western Conference]] Finals: ***[[Utah Jazz]] 109, [[San Antonio Spurs]] 83, '''''San Antonio leads series, 2–1''''' *[[Rugby union]]: **Internationals: ***{{ru|RSA}} 58–10 {{ru|ENG}} at [[Free State Stadium|Vodacom Park]], [[Bloemfontein]] — The Springboks manhandle a depleted England side missing over 30 front-line players due to injuries, illness and club commitments. This is the largest Springboks win in the history of the series. [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/rugby_union/english/6690715.stm (BBC)] ***{{ru|AUS}} 29–23 {{ru|WAL}} at [[Telstra Stadium]], [[Sydney]] — Wallabies substitute [[Stephen Hoiles]] scores a try after the siren to deny Wales their first win on Australian soil since 1969. [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/rugby_union/welsh/6691839.stm (BBC)] ***{{ru|ARG}} 22–20 [[Ireland national rugby union team|Ireland]] at [[Estadio Brigadier General Estanislao López|Estadio B. G. Estanislao López]], [[Santa Fe, Argentina|Santa Fe]] — [[Felipe Contepomi]] gives ''Los Pumas'' the win with a last-minute drop goal, denying Ireland their first-ever win in Argentina. [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/rugby_union/irish/6691995.stm (BBC)] **[[2007 IRB Pacific Nations Cup]]: ***{{ru|FIJ}} 30–15 {{ru|JPN}} **[[2006–07 Top 14 season]]: ***[[Stade Français Paris]] finish at the top of the standings, with [[Stade Toulousain|Toulouse]], [[ASM Clermont Auvergne]] and [[Biarritz Olympique]] making the semi-finals.
<div id="25_May_2007"> </div id>
==25 May 2007 (Friday)==
*[[Cricket]]: **[[Indian cricket team in Bangladesh in 2007]] ***2nd Test-1st Day: {{cr|IND}} 326/0 (90 ov.) lead {{cr|BAN}} by 326 runs **[[West Indian cricket team in England in 2007]] ***2nd Test-1st Day: {{cr|ENG}} 366/5 (85 ov.) lead {{cr|West Indies}} by 366 runs *[[Cycling]]: **[[Bjarne Riis]], winner of the [[1996 Tour de France|1996]] [[Tour de France]], admits to having used the [[doping (sport)|banned drugs]] [[erythropoietin|EPO]], [[cortisone]], and [[growth hormone]] from 1993 to 1998. The current general manager of [[Team CSC]] offered to give back his Tour de France crown. [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/other_sports/cycling/6692779.stm (BBC)] *[[National Hockey League|NHL]]: **Former NHL player [[Rick Tocchet]], currently on leave as an assistant coach with the [[Phoenix Coyotes]], pleads guilty in a [[New Jersey]] court to charges stemming from his [[Operation Slapshot|running of a sports betting ring]]. State authorities have not indicated whether they will seek jail time for Tocchet. [http://sports.espn.go.com/nhl/news/story?id=2882460 (AP via ESPN)]
<div id="24_May_2007"> </div id>
==24 May 2007 (Thursday)==
<div id="23_May_2007"> </div id>
*[[Basketball]]: **[[2007 NBA Playoffs|NBA Playoffs]]: [[Eastern Conference (NBA)|Eastern Conference]] Finals: [[Detroit Pistons]] 79, [[Cleveland Cavaliers]] 76, '''''Detroit leads series, 2–0''''' ***Criticized for passing up a potential game-winning shot in Game 1, [[LeBron James]] misses a would-be go-ahead shot in the final seconds of Game 2. [[Larry Hughes]] gets the rebound but misses an open 10-foot jumper.

[http://www.euroleague.net/main/results/showgame/report?gamecode=228 (Euroleague)] **[[2007 NBA Playoffs|NBA Playoffs]] First Round: ***[[New Jersey Nets]] 98, [[Toronto Raptors]] 97, '''''Nets win series 4–2''''' *[[Ice hockey]] **[[2007 Stanley Cup playoffs|Stanley Cup playoffs]]: Conference Semi Finals: ***[[Buffalo Sabres]] 2, [[New York Rangers]] 1, ''OT''. '''''Sabres lead series 3–2''''' *[[Football (soccer)]]: **[[The Football League]]: [[Leeds United A.F.C.]] are placed into [[Administration (insolvency)|Administration]] and purchased by [[Leeds United Football Club Limited]], controversially chaired by [[Ken Bates]]. Leeds United automatically suffer a 10-point deduction for going into Administration, ensuring their relegation to [[Football League 1]] next season. ''[[History of Leeds United A.F.C.]]''
<div id="3_May_2007"> </div id>
==3 May 2007 (Thursday)==
*[[Basketball]]: **[[NCAA]]: The men's basketball rules committee of the [[National Collegiate Athletic Association]] votes to move the [[three-point field goal|three-point line]] back 1 [[foot (length)|foot]] to 20 feet, 9 inches. If approved by the rules oversight committee on May 25, the change will go into effect in the 2008–09 season. Women's basketball will continue to use the 19'9" line. ([https://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20070503/ap_on_sp_co_ne/bkc_ncaa3_point_line_6 AP via Yahoo]) **[[2007 NBA Playoffs|NBA Playoffs]]: First Round: ***[[Golden State Warriors]] 111, [[Dallas Mavericks]] 86, '''''Warriors win series 4–2.''''' ***The Warriors become the first #8 seed to beat a #1 seed in an NBA best-of-seven series. *[[Football (soccer)]]: **[[2006–07 UEFA Cup]] Semi-finals, second leg. ***{{flagicon|GER}} [[Werder Bremen]] 1–2 '''[[RCD Espanyol|Espanyol]]''' {{flagicon|ESP}} (first leg: 0–3) (aggregate score 1–5) ***{{flagicon|ESP}} '''[[Sevilla FC|Sevilla]]''' 2–0 [[Osasuna]] {{flagicon|ESP}} (first leg: 0–1) (aggregate score 2–1). *[[Ice hockey]] **[[2007 Stanley Cup playoffs|Stanley Cup playoffs]]: Conference Semi Finals: ***[[Anaheim Ducks]] 2, [[Vancouver Canucks]] 1, ''2OT'', '''''Ducks wins series 4–1'''''
<div id="2_May_2007"> </div id>

*[[Tennis]]: **At [[Palma de Mallorca]], [[Rafael Nadal]] defeats [[Roger Federer]], 7–5, 4–6, 7–6 (10), on a specially-designed [[tennis court]], half [[Tennis court#Grass courts|grass]] and half [[Tennis court#Clay courts|clay]]. *[[Football (soccer)]]: **[[2006–07 UEFA Champions League]] Semi Finals, second leg. ***{{flagicon|ITA}} '''[[A.C. Milan]]''' 3–0 [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] {{flagicon|ENG}} (aggregate score 5–3) *[[Ice hockey]]: **[[2007 Stanley Cup playoffs|Stanley Cup playoffs]]: Conference Semi Finals: ***[[Ottawa Senators]] 3, [[New Jersey Devils]] 2, '''''Senators lead series 3–1''''' ***[[Detroit Red Wings]] 3, [[San Jose Sharks]] 2 ''OT'', '''''Series tied 2–2''''' *[[Basketball]]: **[[2007 NBA Playoffs|NBA Playoffs]]: First Round: ***[[San Antonio Spurs]] 93, [[Denver Nuggets]] 78, '''''Spurs win series 4–1''''' ***[[Phoenix Suns]] 119, [[Los Angeles Lakers]] 110, '''''Suns win series 4–1''''' ***After winning both of their Game 5s at home, the Suns and the Spurs will face each other at the Conference Semifinals.

{{Infobox Stadium | name = Palasport Lino Oldrini | nickname = | image = PalaWhirlpool.jpg | fullname = | former_names = Palazzo dello Sport Lino Oldrini
PalaIgnis
PalaWhirlpool
PalA2A | location = Piazzale Antonio Gramsci, 1 21100 [[Varese]], [[Province of Varese|VA]], [[Italy]] | coordinates = {{Coord|45|50|9.96|N|8|48|8.60|E|type:landmark_region:IT||display=inline,title}} | broke_ground = | built = | opened = 6 December 1964[http://digilander.libero.it/Raccontastorie/palazzetto.pdf Digilander.it Palazetto di Masnago o rovine di Pompei? {{it icon}}.] | renovated = 1989, 1995, 2011 | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[Varese|City of Varese]] | operator = | surface = 1,080 mq[http://www.pallacanestrovarese.it/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=44:struttura&catid=10:palawhirpool&Itemid=30 Pallacanestrovarese.it Struttura {{it icon}}.] | scoreboard = | construction_cost = | architect = | project_manager = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | main_contractors = | capacity = [[Basketball]]: 5,300 | record_attendance = | dimensions = 40x27 mt | tenants = [[Pallacanestro Varese]] (1964–present) }} '''Palasport Lino Oldrini''', known as '''Enerxenia Arena''' for sponsorship reasons, is an [[Arena|indoor sporting arena]] that is located in [[Varese]], [[Italy]]. The [[seating capacity]] of the arena is 5,300 people for [[basketball]] games. ==History== The arena hosted the [[1970 Intercontinental Cup (basketball)|1970]] [[FIBA Intercontinental Cup]] basketball tournament. It is currently the home arena of the [[Lega Basket Serie A|Italian League]] professional basketball club [[Pallacanestro Varese]]. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20100913034642/http://www.palaignis.it/ Official site] {{s-start}} {{Succession box | title = [[FIBA Intercontinental Cup]]

[[São Paulo]] }} {{s-end}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Palawhirlpool}} [[Category:Indoor arenas in Italy]] [[Category:Basketball venues in Italy]] [[Category:1964 establishments in Italy]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1964]] {{Italy-sports-venue-stub}}

{{Infobox gymnast |name= Pauline Morel |gender= w |image= Pauline Morel uneven bars.JPG |image_size= |caption= |fullname= |altname= |nickname= |country= {{FRA}} |regions= |formercountry= |birth_date= {{birth date and age|1992|1|3}} |birth_place= |hometown= |residence= |death_date= |death_place= |height= |discipline= WAG |level= Senior International Elite
([[France women's national gymnastics team|France national team]]) |natlteam= 2010 |club= |gym= |collegeteam= |headcoach= |assistcoach= |formercoach= |choreographer= |music= |eponymousskills= |retired= |worldranking= |updated= |show-medals= yes |medaltemplates= }} '''Pauline Morel''' (born 3 January 1992) is a French female [[artistic gymnast]] and part of the national team. She participated at the [[2008 Summer Olympics]].https://www.reuters.com/article/olympics-gymnastics-women-team-events-re-idUSISS85067420080813 She participated at the [[2010 World Artistic Gymnastics Championships]] in Rotterdam, the Netherlands.{{cite web |title=2010 World Gymnastics Championships athletes - Pauline Morel |url=http://gym.longinestiming.com/File/000009010200FFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFF02 |work=LonginesTiming.com |date= |accessdate=27 January 2016}} ==References== ==External links== *http://www.sports-reference.com/olympics/athletes/mo/pauline-morel-1.html *http://www.intlgymnast.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=253&catid=5:competition-reports&Itemid=221 *https://thecscore.wordpress.com/2008/12/17/french-team-training-at-grieux-until-christmas-pauline-morel-to-continue/ *http://www.gettyimages.com/photos/pauline-morel?excludenudity=true&sort=mostpopular&mediatype=photography&phrase=pauline%20morel&family=editorial *https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hmtWKHLciI0 {{DEFAULTSORT:Morel, Pauline}} [[Category:1992 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:French female artistic gymnasts]] [[Category:Place of birth missing (living people)]] [[Category:Olympic gymnasts of France]] [[Category:Gymnasts at the 2008 Summer Olympics]] {{France-sport-stub}} {{France-sport-bio-stub}}

There are 22 '''district Football Associations''' in [[Portugal]]. These organizations are the governing bodies (alongside the [[Portuguese Football Federation]]) of football in each [[Districts of Portugal|Portuguese district]].
==Overview==
Until the reform of Portuguese football in 1948, all clubs in a given district had to participate in the [[Portuguese District Championships|District Championship]], even those in [[Primeira Liga]] and [[Portuguese Second Division|Segunda Divisão]]; after 1948, a [[Portuguese Third Division|Terceira Divisão]] was established for transition between the [[Portuguese District Championships|District Championship]] and national leagues and the top level clubs no longer had to play in their [[Portuguese District Championships|District Championship]] (the arrangement did not include clubs from the [[Azores]] and [[Madeira Islands|Madeira]], which did not reach the top division until the 1970s).
With the reform of Portuguese Football League system in 2013, the [[Campeonato Nacional de Seniores]] became the Portuguese third-level [[association football|football]] league, making the principal [[Portuguese District Championships|District Championship]] the fourth-level leagues.
While the three districts in which the Azores were divided pre-autonomy were abolished, the district football associations haven't merged, and still exist as separate entities. Nevertheless, beginning in 2013, their clubs will compete in a unified Azores league before joining the [[Campeonato Nacional de Seniores]].
==List of district associations==
[[File:Portuguese District Football Associations.png|thumb|300px|Map showing the [[List of municipalities of Portugal|Portuguese municipalities]] arranged by their respective District Football Associations]] The 22 DFAs are:
# ''[[Associação de Futebol do Algarve]]'' (for the [[district of Faro]]) # ''[[Associação de Futebol de Angra do Heroísmo]]'' (former Azorean district of [[Angra do Heroísmo]]) # ''[[Associação de Futebol de Aveiro]]'' ([[district of Aveiro]]) # ''[[Associação de Futebol de Beja]]'' ([[district of Beja]]) # ''[[Associação de Futebol de Braga]]'' ([[district of Braga]]) # ''[[Associação de Futebol de Bragança]]'' ([[district of Bragança]]) # ''[[Associação de Futebol de Castelo Branco]]'' ([[district of Castelo Branco]]) # ''[[Associação de Futebol de Coimbra]]'' ([[district of Coimbra]]) # ''[[Associação de Futebol de Évora]]'' ([[district of Évora]]) # ''[[Associação de Futebol da Guarda]]'' ([[district of Guarda]]) # ''[[Associação de Futebol da Horta]]'' (former Azorean district of [[Horta (Azores)|Horta]]) # ''[[Associação de Futebol de Leiria]]'' ([[district of Leiria]]) # ''[[Associação de Futebol de Lisboa]]'' ([[district of Lisbon]]) # ''[[Associação de Futebol da Madeira]]'' (former Madeiran district of [[Funchal]]) # ''[[Associação de Futebol de Ponta Delgada]]'' (former Azorean district of [[Ponta Delgada]]) # ''[[Associação de Futebol de Portalegre]]'' ([[district of Portalegre]]) # ''[[Associação de Futebol do Porto]]'' ([[district of Oporto]]) # ''[[Associação de Futebol de Santarém]]'' ([[district of Santarém]]) # ''[[Associação de Futebol de Setúbal]]'' ([[district of Setúbal]]) # ''[[Associação de Futebol de Viana do Castelo]]'' ([[district of Viana do Castelo]]) # ''[[Associação de Futebol de Vila Real]]'' ([[district of Vila Real]]) # ''[[Associação de Futebol de Viseu]]'' ([[district of Viseu]])
''Note: '''"Associação de Futebol de/do/da"''' means "Football Association of"''
Angra do Heroísmo, Beja, Bragança, Guarda, Horta and Viana do Castelo have never had representation in the [[Primeira Liga|top level]].
==See also== *[[Brazilian Football State Championships]], a similar system that took root in Portugal's former colony [[Brazil]] and endures due to Brazil's larger size
{{Football in Portugal}}

revision.comment: Reverted to revision 869067639 by [[Special:Contributions/Jmg38|Jmg38]] ([[User talk:Jmg38|talk]]): South London is not in Croydon! ([[WP:TW|TW]])
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2015}} {{Use British English|date=September 2015}} {{infobox UK place| |country = England |region= London |population= 12,777 |population_ref= (2011 Ward)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.neighbourhood.statistics.gov.uk/dissemination/LeadKeyFigures.do?a=7&b=13688667&c=Sanderstead&d=14&e=62&g=6322674&i=1001x1003x1032x1004&o=362&m=0&r=1&s=1476095613123&enc=1|title=Croydon Ward population 2011|accessdate=10 October 2016|publisher=Office for National Statistics |work=Neighbourhood Statistics}}</ref> |official_name= Sanderstead |static_image_name= All Saints' Church, Sanderstead CR2 - geograph.org.uk - 84937.jpg |static_image_caption = All Saints' Church, floodlit. |london_borough= Croydon |post_town= SOUTH CROYDON |postcode_area= CR |postcode_district= CR2 |dial_code= 020 |os_grid_reference= TQ337613 |coordinates = {{coord|51.3358|-0.0818|display=inline,title}} |constituency_westminster= [[Croydon South (UK Parliament constituency)|Croydon South]] }} '''Sanderstead''' {{IPAc-en|ˈ|s|ɑː|n|d|ɚ|s|t|ɛ|d}} is a village and medieval-founded church parish in the [[London Borough of Croydon]]. It takes in '''Purley Downs''' and the Sanderstead Plantation, a large wooded park that includes the animated second-[[List of highest points in London|highest point in London]]. The area sits above a [[wind gap|dry valley]] at the edge of the built-up area of [[Greater London]]. Cementing its secular identity from the late 19th century until abolition in 1965 it had a [[civil parishes in England|civil parish]] council.{{refn|group=n|for the last fifty years of which, the CPC was an inferior body to the [[Coulsdon and Purley Urban District]] of [[Surrey]], co-run by [[Surrey County Council]] and all of the London Borough of Croydon formed in 1965 lay in the latter county as 1965 saw the county's second major reduction}}<ref>Vision of Britain - [http://www.visionofbritain.org.uk/unit/10147232/boundary Sanderstead civil parish boundary]</ref><ref>The Church of England [http://www.achurchnearyou.com/church/782/ Sanderstead ecclesiastical parish boundary]</ref> The community had a smaller farming-centred economy until the mid 19th century.
[[All Saints, Sanderstead|All Saints' Church's]] construction began in about 1230 followed by great alterations and affixing of monuments including a poem attributed to [[John Dryden]], the first [[Poet Laureate of the United Kingdom|Poet Laureate]] nationally; it is protected under UK law as [[Grade I]] [[listed building|listed]].<ref>'Parishes: Sanderstead', ''[[Victoria County History|A History of the County of Surrey]]'': Volume 4, ed. H E Malden (London, 1912), pp. 237-243. British History Online http://www.british-history.ac.uk/vch/surrey/vol4/pp237-243 [accessed 24 May 2018].</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.britishlistedbuildings.co.uk/en-201146-church-of-all-saints-croydon|title=Church of All Saints, Croydon, London|first=Good|last=Stuff|date=|website=www.britishlistedbuildings.co.uk|accessdate=19 April 2018}}</ref> [[Sanderstead railway station|Sanderstead station]] is at the foot of the dry valley and has frequent, fast trains to [[East Croydon station|East Croydon]], connected to a range of [[London]] terminals and interchanges.{{refn|group=n|Other direct destinations are further from London: [[East Grinstead]] and [[Uckfield]]}} Sanderstead is claimed to an origin of the English [[Sanders (surname)|Sanders]] surname,<ref>Generations, a Thousand Year Family History by Ralph Sanders; {{ISBN|1425795722}}</ref> noting at least four separate geographical clusters formed by the 19th century, two of which were by 1881 far more populous.<ref>[http://gbnames.publicprofiler.org/Map.aspx?name=SANDERS&year=1881&altyear=1998&country=GB&type=name Sanders surname in 1881 map of England]</ref>
Sanderstead's [[Interwar]] growth coincided with electrification of the [[Southern Railway (UK)|Southern Railway]] leaving largely a [[suburb]]an community of households having at least one commuter to central London or [[Croydon]].
== History == [[File:Sanderstead church.jpg|thumb|The Grade I listed All Saints' Church, Sanderstead]] There is evidence of prehistoric human activity in and around Sanderstead. In 1958–60 the Sanderstead Archaeological Group excavated in the vicinity of Sanderstead pond and revealed the presence of man as far back as the Mesolithic Period nearly 12,000 years ago, as well as pottery fragments dated between 100 AD and 1300 AD and a bronze belt from the end of the Saxon era.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.croydon.gov.uk/leisure/parksandopenspaces/parksatoz/sandersteadpond/ssphistory |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-01-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140112163500/http://www.croydon.gov.uk/leisure/parksandopenspaces/parksatoz/sandersteadpond/ssphistory |archivedate=12 January 2014 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> North of the village at [[Croham Hurst]], upon a wooded hill, are circular barrows believed to be from a [[Bronze Age]] settlement. This is now part of a public open space and the site is marked by a brass monument. A [[Romano-British]] homestead (small farming settlement) was discovered during the construction of the Atwood School. During the 1980s, when the school was extended, further excavation revealed the remains of several round huts, hearths, a brooch, and pottery, some of which hailed from [[North Africa]].
An [[Old English language|Anglo-Saxon]] reference to Sanderstead can be found in the will, dated 871, of Alfred, an ealdorman. The village lay within the [[Anglo-Saxons|Anglo-Saxon]] administrative division of [[Wallington (hundred)|Wallington]] [[hundred (division)|hundred]]. It later appears to have been given to St Peter's Abbey, Winchester ([[Hyde Abbey]]) by Æthelflæd, the wife of [[Edgar the Peaceful]] and mother of [[Edward the Martyr]], where it remained after the [[Norman Conquest]].<ref>A topographical history of Surrey, by E.W. Brayley assisted by J. Britton ... By Edward Wedlake Brayley, John Britton, page 40</ref>
Sanderstead appears in the [[Domesday Book]] of 1086 as ''Sandestede'', and belonging to St Peter's Abbey, Winchester. It had a noted population (probably of just the adult males) of 26 including 21 villagers, 4 slaves and 1 cottager.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://domesdaymap.co.uk/place/TQ3461/sanderstead/|title=Index of /place/TQ3461/sanderstead/|author=|date=|website=domesdaymap.co.uk|accessdate=19 April 2018}}</ref> Its Domesday assets were assessed as 5 [[hide (unit)|hide]]s, and 10 [[carucate]]s of arable land. It had 9 [[plough]]s and wood worth 30 [[hog (swine)|hog]]s.<ref>[http://www.gwp.enta.net/surrnames.htm Surrey Domesday Book] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070715015325/http://www.gwp.enta.net/surrnames.htm |date=15 July 2007 }}</ref> Its Domesday entry records that in the time of [[Edward the Confessor]] it was valued at 100 shillings, and now 12 pounds; and yet it produces 15 pounds.<ref>A topographical history of Surrey, by E.W. Brayley assisted by J. Britton ... By Edward Wedlake Brayley, John Britton, Page 40</ref>
The village was granted to [[Sir John Gresham]] by [[Henry VIII]] following the [[Dissolution of the Monasteries]]. It was passed to his son Richard who subsequently sold it to John Ownsted, the transfer being ratified in 1591. Ownsted died without issue in 1600, and devised his estates to his two sisters and cousin Harman Atwood, with Atwood subsequently purchasing the shares of his joint legatees. The Atwood family had a long association with Sanderstead, with inscriptions at the local church indicating a presence in the village from the reign of [[Edward II]].<ref>A topographical history of Surrey, by E.W. Brayley assisted by J. Britton ... By Edward Wedlake Brayley, John Britton, Page 41</ref>
On Monday, 6 September 1731, the nearby Sanderstead Common was the venue for an [[First-class cricket#Important matches classification|important cricket match]] between [[Surrey county cricket teams|Surrey]] and [[Thomas Chambers' XI cricket team|Thomas Chambers' XI]], Surrey winning the match by an unknown margin.<ref>Buckley, p. 6.</ref> On Monday, 26 June 1732, Surrey played [[London Cricket Club|London]] on the common. This match was drawn.<ref>Buckley, p. 7.</ref>
The [[manor house]], known as [[Sanderstead Court]], was substantially remodelled by Harman Atwood. This large country house was probably first constructed in the early sixteenth century. The Atwoods continued to occupy the house until 1778, when it was devised to Atwood Wigsell. It was turned into a hotel in 1928, and before the [[Second World War]] it was used by the [[Royal Air Force]] (RAF). It was very badly damaged by fire (not a bomb) in 1944 and was demolished in 1958. One very small part of the hotel building does however still stand. On the site now stands "Sanderstead Court", a three-storey block of flats.
One of the more curious aspects of Sanderstead is that it has no pub, unlike nearby [[Warlingham]] which has around six.
On the edge of the village lies the site of the Old Saw Mill now home to a number of private residences and the picturesque setting for Sanderstead Cricket Club. Cricket has been played here since 1883 and continues to the present day with four teams playing in the Surrey Championship and a number of other Colts and friendly teams.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sanderstead.play-cricket.com/website/web_pages/80378|title=Sanderstead CC|author=|date=|website=sanderstead.play-cricket.com|accessdate=19 April 2018}}</ref>
Located between Limpsfield Road and Kingswood Lane is the large ''Kings Wood''. It derives its name from a small wood to the north of Kings Wood Lodge. In 1823, Ordnance Survey Maps called the wood Sanderstead Wood, but this might be due to a mistake. It covers some 147½ acres, criss-crossed by ancient rides and is on relatively flat ground. It was purchased in 1937 under the Green Belt Act by the local council and is now public open space. There is the site of a Romano-British settlement on the northern boundary, a small farmstead undisturbed for 2000 years.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.croydononline.org/history/places/parks_and_open_spaces/kingswood.asp|title=Online communities|author=|date=22 January 2016|website=croydononline.org|accessdate=19 April 2018}}</ref>
==Education== Sanderstead has four schools, namely; Atwood Primary School, Gresham Primary School, Kingsdown Secondary School and Ridgeway Primary School. It is also conveniently placed for a number of others located within a couple of miles from the village including [[Croydon High School]], [[Harris Academy Purley]], [[Riddlesdown Collegiate]], [[Royal Russell School]], [[The Quest Academy, Croydon|The Quest Academy]], [[Thomas More Catholic School, Purley|Thomas More Catholic School]], [[Warlingham School]], and [[Whitgift School]].
==Demography== The 2011 census showed that White British was the largest ethnic group in Sanderstead ward, forming 76% of the population.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ukcensusdata.com/sanderstead-e05000160|title=Sanderstead - UK Census Data 2011|first=Good Stuff IT|last=Services|date=|website=UK Census Data|accessdate=19 April 2018}}</ref>
==Politics== Sanderstead has consistently returned [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative Party]] MPs to the local seat of [[Croydon South (UK Parliament constituency)|Croydon South]] and has also returned Conservative members to the local council. Since the north of Croydon tends to return [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour]] councillors, a near-identical split in representation follows. The current MP for Croydon South is [[Chris Philp]].
Sanderstead is one of the twenty-four [[ward (country subdivision)|ward]]s constituting [[Croydon London Borough Council]]. Three councillors are elected every four years to represent the ward on the Council. The current elected Councillors are:
{| class="wikitable" |- !colspan="2"|Elected!!Member!!Ward |- |style="background-color: {{Conservative Party (UK)/meta/color}}" | |1998 |Lynne Hale || Sanderstead |- |style="background-color: {{Conservative Party (UK)/meta/color}}" | |2002 |Timothy Pollard || Sanderstead |- |style="background-color: {{Conservative Party (UK)/meta/color}}" | |2006 |Yvette Hopley || Sanderstead |} {{Election box begin | title=Sanderstead 2018 (3)}} {{Election box winning candidate with party link| |party = Conservative Party (UK) |candidate = Lynne Hale |votes = 3,971 |percentage = |change = }} {{Election box winning candidate with party link| |party = Conservative Party (UK) |candidate = Yvette Hopley |votes = 3,954 |percentage = |change = }} {{Election box winning candidate with party link| |party = Conservative Party (UK) |candidate = Timothy Pollard |votes = 3,944 |percentage = |change = }}

==Notable residents== In alphabetical order: *[[John Atwood (Assistant Governor)|John Atwood]] (1576–1644) was the Assistant Governor of the [[Plymouth Colony]], in the US state of [[Massachusetts]], in 1638. His childhood was spent at [[Sanderstead Court]]. *[[Margaret Bondfield]] (1873–1953), the first woman to sit in Cabinet in the United Kingdom (1929-1931), died in Sanderstead on 16 June 1953.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/72848/Margaret-Bondfield|title=Margaret Bondfield - British labour leader|author=|date=|website=britannica.com|accessdate=19 April 2018}}</ref> *[[Laurier Lister]] (1907–1986), theatre director and producer, was born in the village.<ref>IMDb [https://www.imdb.com/name/nm6735159/?ref_=fn_al_nm_1 Retrieved 10 August 2018.</ref> *[[Stephen Rumbold Lushington]] (1775–1868) lived for a time at [[Sanderstead Court]], and his daughter was born there in 1816. He was Joint Secretary of the Treasury (1824–7), Governor of Madras (1827–32), and MP for Rye (1807–12) and for Canterbury (1812–30). *[[I, Ludicrous]] lead singer David Rippingale, aka William Hung, spent his formative years in Sanderstead (1958–71). * [[Kate Moss]], model, lived in Addiscombe and then Sanderstead as a teenager. She went to Ridgeway Primary School, then Riddlesdown High School. *[[Malcolm Muggeridge]] was born in Broomhall Road on 24 March 1903.<ref>''My Life in Pictures'' {{ISBN|0-906969-60-3}}</ref> *[[Ruth Ellis]] (1926–1955), the last woman to be executed in the UK, lived on Sanderstead Hill. *[[Kray Twins|Charlie Kray]], criminal and elder brother of gangsters Ronald and Reggie Kray, lived for a time in Limpsfield Road.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/kray-on-drugs-charges-1307719.html|title=Kray on drugs charges|author=|date=2 August 1996|website=independent.co.uk|accessdate=19 April 2018}}</ref>

{{unreferenced|date=May 2015}} {{Infobox cricket ground | ground_name = Sargodha Cricket Stadium | nickname = Sargodha Stadium | image = | caption = | country = [[Pakistan]] | location = [[Sargodha]], [[Punjab, Pakistan|Punjab]], [[Pakistan]] | coordinates = {{coord|32|30|3|N|74|33|14|E|type:landmark|display=it}} | establishment = 1940 | seating_capacity = 30,000 | owner = Sargodha Division Cricket Association | tenants = [[Pakistan Cricket Board]] | end1 = Pavilion End | end2 = Railway End | international = true | firstodidate = 10 jan | firstodiyear = 1992 | firstodihome = Pakistan | firstodiaway = Sri Lanka | lastodidate = 14 September | lastodiyear = 1997 | lastodihome = Pakistan | lastodiaway = West Indies | year2 = | club2 = | year1 = 2003 – present | club1 = [[Sargodha cricket team]] | date = 10 October | year = 2003 | source = }}
The '''Sargodha Cricket Stadium''' is a cricket [[stadium]] located in [[Sargodha]], [[Punjab, Pakistan|Punjab]], [[Pakistan]] . It is within walking distance of the [[University of Sargodha]] (UOS) and part of the Local Sports and Entertainment Precinct.
The Stadium was firstly used in 1954. It only hosted on Jan 10, 1992.
Internationally, Sargodha Stadium is remembered as the first match of series 1991-92 between Pakistan and Sri Lanka was played in this stadium. Pakistan won this match easily by securing victory by 8 wickets. That was the first international match it has hosted and the last one so far. The open-air stadium is also famous for its role in the development of local cricket. Many youngsters attend practice sessions in the stadium. Many local events like sports functions by local universities, colleges and schools.
The Sargodha Stadium, also known as Sports Stadium, Sargodha, has hosted other events, including a picket by PTI's Chairman and former cricketer Imran Khan and by some other famous leaders too, and also hosts major musical concerts.

[[File:Scoring in Gaelic games - H shaped posts.png|thumb|Goalposts and scoring system used in [[hurling]], [[Gaelic football]], [[camogie]], [[ladies' Gaelic football]] and [[shinty-hurling]].]] This page discusses '''scoring''' in the [[Gaelic games]] of [[hurling]], [[Gaelic football]], [[camogie]], [[ladies' Gaelic football]], [[international rules football]] and [[shinty-hurling]].
Note that although [[rounders]] and [[Gaelic handball]] are considered "Gaelic games", they are not listed under this page.
==Scoring== In [[hurling]], [[Gaelic football]], [[camogie]], [[ladies' Gaelic football]] and [[shinty-hurling]], the goalposts are placed {{Convert|6.5|m|abbr=on}} apart and are at least {{Convert|7|m|abbr=on}} tall,<ref>http://ww.w.thesmartjournal.com/GAA.pdf</ref> with a crossbar at a height of {{Convert|2.5|m|abbr=on}}. Playing the ball (a [[sliotar]] or [[Ball (Gaelic football)|Gaelic football]], depending on the game) between the posts and below the crossbar scores a '''goal''' ({{Lang-ga|cúl}}), while playing the ball between the posts and above the crossbar scores a '''point''' (''cúilín''). A goal is worth 3 points. The [[umpire]] signifies a goal by waving a green flag, and a point by waving a white flag. These flags have been used since the 1900s; one game in the [[United States]] in 1907 used a US flag to signify points, and an Irish flag (presumably the [[Irish tricolour|tricolour]]) for a goal.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.ie/books?id=U3K3DQAAQBAJ&pg=PA22&dq=%22green+flag%22+%22white+flag%22+first+used+gaa&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiQ_LCppMXeAhWsAMAKHWVeDAEQ6AEIKDAA#v=onepage&q=flag&f=false|title=On the Cross Road of Polity, Political Elites and Mobilization|first1=Barbara|last1=Wejnert|first2=Paolo|last2=Parigi|date=21 December 2016|publisher=Emerald Group Publishing|via=Google Books}}</ref> [[File:International Rules Football scores.png|thumb|400px|Scoring in [[international rules football]].]] In [[international rules football]] there are further posts {{Convert|6.5|m|abbr=on}} either side of the goalposts. Playing the ball between the goalposts and these side posts scores a '''behind'''. Playing the ball between the centre posts and below the crossbar scores a '''goal''', while playing the ball between the posts and above the crossbar scores an '''over'''. A goal is worth 6 points, an over 3, and a behind 1.
===Terminology===
The Irish term for goal is ''cúl'', [[cognate]] with [[Latin]] [[wikt:culus|''cūlus'']], "rear." "Point" is ''cúilín'', a [[diminutive]] form.
==History==
===First GAA rules=== The first [[Gaelic football]] and [[hurling]] rules were published by the fledgling [[Gaelic Athletic Association]] in 1885. These specified goalposts similar to [[soccer]] goals: for football {{Convert|15|ft|abbr=on}} wide and a crossbar {{Convert|8|ft|abbr=on}} high, while for hurling they were {{Convert|20|ft|abbr=on}} wide and a crossbar {{Convert|10|ft|abbr=on}} high. Goals were the only score possible; this led to a high number of drawn games.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://webcache.googleusercontent.com/search?q=cache:tOlW8_iW0gMJ:https://www.nli.ie/GetAttachment.aspx?id=4833289f-fd82-4978-9471-eceff459cb06+&cd=36&hl=en&ct=clnk&gl=ie|title=LEAVING CERTIFICATE HISTORY CASE STUDY|website=webcache.googleusercontent.com}}</ref>
In 1886 two poles were placed {{Convert|21|ft|abbr=on}} either side of the goals.<ref>https://www.museum.ie/The-Collections/Documentation-Discoveries/July-2015/Gaelic-Athletic-Association-Football-Rules-Book,-1</ref> A goal was scored when the ball was played into the goal; a point was scored when the ball was played above the crossbar, or wide of the goals between the two outer posts. When the ball was played wide of the outer posts, no score was recorded, unless it was played by a defernder, in which case a ''forfeit point'' was awarded.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://irishamerica.com/2017/02/up-tipp-hurling-nationalism/|title=Up Tipp: Hurling & Nationalism|date=1 February 2017|publisher=}}</ref><ref>https://crokepark.ie/BlankSite/media/Images/secondary-schools-resource-pack.pdf</ref>
Whichever team scored most goals won the game; if teams were tied on goals, points were counted, and forfeit points were worth {{fraction|5}} of a point. Forfeit points thus rarely made any difference, although one game in 1887 ended North Tipperary 0-0 (1), Holycross 0-0 (0).<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.ie/books?id=D4pZDwAAQBAJ&pg=PT140&lpg=PT140&dq=%22forfeit+point%22+hurling&source=bl&ots=22xZ7yHfAq&sig=TtXA-qGJp6EBu_T2-oe-wjcSEVQ&hl=en&sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwiU3NGcl8PeAhWSbsAKHexIAuYQ6AEwB3oECAQQAQ#v=onepage&q=%22forfeit+point%22&f=false|title=The Hurlers: The First All-Ireland Championship and the Making of Modern Hurling|first=Paul|last=Rouse|date=6 September 2018|publisher=Penguin UK|via=Google Books}}</ref>
The score was written in the format ''goals''–''points'' (''forfeit points''), e.g. Tipperary's score of 1-1 (1) in the [[1887 All-Ireland Senior Hurling Championship Final]] ===Changes=== {| class="wikitable" style="font-size:97%; text-align:center; float:right;" |+Value of scores !width="80"|Period !width="50"|Goal !Point !Forfeit point |- !1885 | 1 || colspan="2"|''n/a'' |- !1886–87 | rowspan="2"|∞ || rowspan="4"|1 || {{fraction|5}} |- !1888–91 | rowspan="3"|'' n/a'' |- !1892–95 |5 |- !1896–present |3 |} In 1888 the forfeit point was abolished, replaced by a {{Convert|70|yd|abbr=on}} puck in hurling and a {{Convert|50|yd|abbr=on}} kick in football. Hurling and Gaelic football goals were made the same size: {{Convert|21|ft|abbr=on}} by {{Convert|8|ft|abbr=on}}.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.ie/books?id=UtQJAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA31&lpg=PA31&dq=GAA+goalposts+%22feet+apart%22&source=bl&ots=sCnvbDUZe1&sig=Y5tfwXo_C0qyO7KY-Sk2aE7aGc4&hl=en&sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwjWyezGncPeAhVkIcAKHXT2DboQ6AEwGXoECAsQAQ#v=onepage&q=GAA+goalposts+%22feet+apart%22&f=false|title=The reliable book of outdoor games|first=H.|last=Chadwick|date=7 November 1893|publisher=Рипол Классик|via=Google Books}}</ref>
In 1892 the goal was changed to be worth five points.
In 1896 the goal was reduced to three points, and has held that value ever since.
In 1910 the side posts were removed, and the H-shaped goalposts introduced. Now, a point had to go over the crossbar.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.rte.ie/sport/gaa/2018/0713/978456-the-7-ages-of-hurling/|title=The Game - 7 Ages of Hurling|first=Mikey|last=Stafford|date=15 July 2018|publisher=}}</ref>
===Modern experiments=== In the [[2005 National Hurling League]] two points were awarded for a point scored from a sideline cut in hurling, in recognition of the difficulty of this skill (typically only about one-fifth of such efforts are successful).<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.ie/sport/hurling/ladies-sticking-with-skirts-as-oflynn-backs-rules-makeover-26837681.html|title=Ladies sticking with skirts as O'Flynn backs rules makeover - Independent.ie|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.ie/sport/gaelic-games/hurling/cutting-edge-line-art-still-a-major-draw-36785192.html|title=Cutting edge: Line art still a major draw - Independent.ie|publisher=}}</ref>
The idea of increasing the value of the goal to 4 points has come up repeatedly in recent years.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.balls.ie/gaa/almost-every-known-solution-improve-gaa-past-20-years-233953|title=Every Known Solution To Improve The GAA In The Past 20 Years|first=Conor|last=Neville|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gaa.ie/the-gaa/games/hurling-review-committee|title=Hurling Review Committee|website=www.gaa.ie}}</ref> ==Frequency==
An oft-repeated aphorism, especially with regard to Gaelic football, is "points win games" or "take your points and the goals will come."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://gaacork.ie/taggedNews/47537/cork_football_teams_v_clare|title=Cork GAA Official Website|website=gaacork.ie}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.irishexaminer.com/sport/gaa/hurling/take-the-points-and-the-goals-334970.html|title=Take the points and the goals...|date=6 June 2015|publisher=}}</ref> This has become especially true in recent decades: in the mid-1970s, games in the [[All-Ireland Senior Football Championship]] averaged 3.5 goals, but in the 2000s this had fallen to 1 goal per game. [[Martin Breheny]] observed "Improved fitness levels, more mobile defenders, and better defensive techniques have combined to seal off attackers' approach routes, making the goal an endangered species." Raising the value to 4 or even 5 points has been suggested.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.ie/sport/gaelic-games/gaelic-football/time-for-the-gaa-to-reassess-its-football-goals-26084096.html|title=Time for the GAA to re-assess its football goals - Independent.ie|publisher=}}</ref>
In hurling, goals per game has decreased from a peak of 4.18 per game in 1983, in part because of a rule change that banned handpassed goals.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.rte.ie/sport/gaa/2018/0806/983440-the-art-of-the-assassin-the-lust-for-green-flags/|title=The art of the 'assassin' & the lust for green flags|first=Christy|last=O'Connor|date=6 August 2018|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://hurlingfacts.wordpress.com/2011/07/06/is-point-scoring-really-increasing-in-championship-hurling/|title=Is point scoring really increasing in Championship Hurling?|date=6 July 2011|publisher=}}</ref>
==Notation==
A particular notation has been developed over the years by journalists and statisticians to record scoring in Gaelic games.
===Score by team===
A team's score is given in the form ''goals-points'', separated by either a [[hyphen]] ( - ) or [[en dash]] ( – ), for example ''Kerry 2-10 Cork 1-12''. The total points score may be given in brackets afterward for clarity: ''Kerry 2-10 (16) Cork 1-12 (15)''. Unlike other sports, where the home team's name is given before the away team, in Gaelic games the winning team's name is almost always given first.
Scores are spoken aloud thus: *0-20: "twenty points" *1-6: "one six" *3-17: "three seventeen" *2-0: "two goals" *0-0: "no score"
In [[international rules football]], the score is given in the format ''goals.overs.points (total)'', for example the [[2014 International Rules Series]] ended [[Australia international rules football team|Australia]] 0.17.5 (56), [[Ireland international rules football team|Ireland]] 2.9.7 (46).
===Score by player===
In newspaper and other written accounts of games, the score of each individual player is given in abbreviated format. First the total is given, and then it is broken down by [[dead ball]] scores. *'''f''' or '''fs''': free kicks / free pucks *'''pen''': penalty kicks / penalty pucks *'''<nowiki>'</nowiki>45<nowiki>'</nowiki>''' or '''<nowiki>‘</nowiki>45''': 45-metre kick (awarded in [[Gaelic football]] and [[ladies Gaelic football]] when a defender plays the ball over his/her own end line, like a [[corner kick]] in soccer); a 45-metre puck is awarded in [[camogie]] *'''<nowiki>'</nowiki>65<nowiki>'</nowiki>''' or '''<nowiki>‘</nowiki>65''': 65-metre puck (awarded in [[hurling]] when a defender plays the ball over his own end line) *'''s/l''' or '''sl''': sideline kicks / sideline pucks * Scores from open play are not indicated; any scores not accounted for by dead ball are from open play by default.
So if a report says ''James Kelly 2-5 (1-1f, 1-0pen, 0-2 '45')'', it means that he scored 2 goals and 5 points, of which a goal and a point were from frees, a goal from a penalty, two points from 45-metre kicks, and the other two points were from open play. If no goals are scored, the ''0-'' will be omitted, e.g. ''Michael O'Shea 0-9 (5f, 1 '65', 1 s/l)''. If all scores were of one type, the brackets may be omitted, reading: ''Síle Harrington 0-5f'' (indicating five points, all of which were frees) or ''J. J. Maguire 1-0pen'' (one goal, a penalty) or sometimes ''Sarah Moore 0-4(fs)''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hoganstand.com/Type/football/Article/Index/280780|title=FL2: Rossies rally stuns Premier - HoganStand|website=www.hoganstand.com}}</ref>

{{more footnotes|date=August 2013}} [[File:Skimboarding Seal Beach 11 25 11.webm|thumb|Ski at [[Seal Beach, California|Seal Beach]], 2011]] '''Skimboarding''' (or '''skimming''') is a [[boardsport]] in which a ''skimboard'' (much like a [[surfboard]] but smaller and without fins) is used to glide across the water's surface to meet an incoming [[breaking wave]], and ride it back to shore. Wave-riding skimboarders perform a variety of surface and air maneuvers, at various stages of their ride, out to, and back with, the wave. Some of these are known as "wraps," "big spins," "360 shove-its" and "180s." Unlike surfing, skimboarding begins on the [[beach]] by dropping the board onto the thin wash of previous waves. Skimboarders use their [[momentum]] to skim out to breaking waves, which they then catch back into shore in a manner similar to surfing. [[File:Bigspin at Kiahuna Beach.jpg|thumb|200px|Skimboarder|Poipu Beach Kauai,Hawaii]] Another aspect of skimboarding is "flatland," which involves performing tricks derived from skateboarding such as [[Ollie (skateboarding trick)|ollies]] and [[shove-it]]s on the wash of waves without catching [[Surf break|shore break]]s. Skimboarding originated in [[Southern California]] when [[Laguna Beach, California|Laguna Beach]] [[lifeguard]]s wanted to surf the local [[Surf break|shore breaks]] that were too fast and shallow for surfboards. Skimboarding has developed since then to ride waves much like surfing, performing [[aerial maneuvers]] and pulling into the barrel of the wave. Professionals have even started getting towed by [[WaveRunner|waverunners]] into much larger waves. Professional Skimboarder, [http://exileskimboards.com/team/brad-domke/ Brad Domke], displayed the new technique in this video.<ref>{{Citation|last=ExileSkimboards|title=The Biggest Wave Ever Ridden On A Skimboard - Brad Domke - Exile Skimboards|date=2014-07-12|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2Cu0VnsWNTI|accessdate=2017-03-01}}</ref>
==Skimboard characteristics== {{unreferenced section|date=May 2016}} [[File:Surfwax.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Man applying [[surfboard wax]] to a skimboard.]] Riders typically favor a board [[length]] which reaches about their mid-[[chest]] height when stood on end.
Thickness of the board depends somewhat on the [[materials]] used in construction, but typically ranges from 3/8 inch to 1 inch. The most common thicknesses are 5/8" and 3/4". A few high-flotation [[foam]] core boards and "soft" boards have been built with thicknesses in excess of 2 inches. A 5/8 board is capable of sharper turns while sacrificing a little speed. A 3/4 will be able to glide out farther, but turns slightly slower.
Most skimboards will have some nose lift, or rocker. There are three types of rockers generally used for skimboards. There is a constant rocker, which means that the board has a constant curve from nose to tail. Constant rockers are known for better control on bigger waves and steeper slopes. Another type of rocker and the most commonly used is a hybrid rocker. This means that the board has a curve on the bottom through about 3/4 of the board's length, the rest (meaning the flat part) is usually the tail. This type of rocker is good for both speed and control on decent size waves; also the best type of board for flatland tricks. Last of all, a traditional rocker means that the board is almost completely flat except for the nose. A traditional rocker is typically used for east coast conditions where the waves are far out.
==Dangers== {{unreferenced section|date=May 2016}} There are many types of [[risk|dangers]] that skimboarders can face on a daily basis. It is not uncommon to see [[bone fracture|fractures]] or [[joint dislocation|dislocations]] of the lower limbs, some requiring serious [[Health care (disambiguation)|medical attention]]. [[Lacerations]], [[Sprained ankle|twisted ankles]] and [[bruises]] are also common, due to impacts with the board itself, or [[rocks]], logs and other obstacles present on beaches. [[Hamstring]] injury is also common due to the fast and extreme movement of a skimboarder's legs when they run toward the water and jump on the board. [[Drowning]] amongst skimboarders is not as likely as amongst surfers due to the shallow water in which skimboarding is usually practiced. Also, due to the shallow water, [[cervical fracture]] is a very dangerous possibility when riding big waves.
A study was done in a British journal on the dangers of skimboarding, and it states, "Over a 5 month period—May to September 2003, 10 patients were seen by the fracture team at the [[Royal Cornwall Hospitals NHS Trust]]. Of the 10, eight were male, with an average age 18.7 (range 12–31). There was an equal incidence of left and right sided injuries. All the injuries were closed with no neurovascular [[symptoms]] or signs. Eight were to the lower limb, all of which were fractures of the [[distal tibia]], [[ankle]], and mid-foot. Six patients required hospital admission. . . [all of these injuries were from skimboarding]"<ref>{{cite journal|title=Dangers of skimboarding|author=|date=1 November 2006|publisher=|journal=British Journal of Sports Medicine|volume=40|issue=11|pages=905|pmc=2465017}}</ref>
Many injuries that skimboarders suffer happen over a long period of time. Such injuries include: groin strain, fractures, leg pains, [[shin splints]], etc. Some of these injuries can be prevented by [[stretching]] before and after a session.
Another foot injury that can occur is "skimboard toe". Much like "[[turf toe]]," it develops from overuse and can eventually break bones in your foot.
Other dangers to consider while skimboarding are [[riptide]]s. They can be very strong in certain areas and bring a skimboarder out to [[sea]] very quickly. There have been a few incidences of skimboarders dying from drowning by being caught in a riptide.{{citation needed|date=February 2018}} Many skimboarders{{who|date=August 2013}} recommend asking locals about [[tides]] and swells as well as checking tide charts if skimming in a new area. Doing so will also help avoid rocks that are hidden under waves, which are another potential cause of serious injury.
==Locations== {{unreferenced section|date=May 2016}} Many consider the center of skimboarding to be located in Laguna Beach, California where skimboarding became popular in the late 1920s when lifeguards would skim across [[sand]] on pieces of wood. Every [[summer]], Victoria Skimboards sponsors a contest called the VIC, which is held at Aliso Beach in Laguna; it is one of the biggest skimboarding competitions in the [[world]]. Other Laguna hot spots consist of Tenth street, West Street, Treasure Island, Thalia Street, and Crescent Bay. In [[Dewey Beach, Delaware]], every year the World Amateur Championships of Skimboarding are held on New Orleans Street. The Florida Pro/Am is held every year in August, on [[Vilano Beach, Florida]], which is known as the best [[East Coast of the United States|East Coast]] skimboarding location. Big skimboarding waves are also found in [[Cabo San Lucas, Mexico]]. However, people skim in many other locations throughout [[North America]], [[Europe]] (the main locations being [[Portugal]], [[France]], [[Spain]], [[british isles|United Kingdom]] & the [[Netherlands]]), [[Australia]], [[Asia]], and [[South America]]. Some people skim [[Inland navigation|inland]] because of difficulty with shore access. Flatland skimboarding can be done nearly anywhere: [[lakes]], [[rivers]], [[Stream|creeks]], [[ponds]], [[golf courses]], [[puddles]], or even wet [[grass]]. In the [[United States]], flatland skim scenes have developed primarily in states not bordering the ocean. Flatland has also developed in British Columbia, [[Ontario]], and along The [[Great Lakes]].
Australia (Melbourne and [[Parramatta]]), and [[Wellington]], [[New Zealand]] also have dedicated flatland communities and riders. In Europe, the Flatland skim scene is growing fast, with the biggest group of skimboarders situated in [[Poland]]. Skimboarding is popular on many beaches where it is impossible to surf, for example, on [[Boa Viagem, Recife]], Brazil, where surfing is banned due to the threat of shark attacks. Beaches that have streams or rivers flowing into the ocean can also make ideal downhill skimming areas.
== Types of skimboards == {{Multiple issues|section=yes| {{expand section|date=August 2013}} {{unreferenced section|date=May 2016}} }} '''Wave Riding Skimboards'''
Wave riding is the style most popular and best recognized in the sport of skimboarding. There are more athletes and competitions in wave riding than any other division of skimboarding. It is also the hardest and most technical. Today's wave riding boards are a product of years of trials and errors. There isn't much variation in shape because of this. There is a wide variety of beginner to very advanced, high performance boards in this category and it is important to choose the right one for your size, ability and style. Wave riding skimboarders refer to their board as a "skimboard." However to inland skimborders it is referred to as a "foamie."
The majority of wave riding skimboard manufacturers use a closed cell foam, which is a high density foam material that resists water absorption and dings. A [[Fiber-reinforced polymer]] is commonly used to cover the foam forming a strong outer shell.
[[Fiberglass]] boards are great, compared to the wooden board. They are faster, lighter, and they have more control on the water. The fiberglass behaves across the sand and water better, which is important for doing tricks and moves with the skimboard when it hit the wave. Its outer shell is strong, but easy to dent with rocks, shells, like any other composite skimboard.
[[Carbon fiber]] boards are lighter, stronger, and stiffer than the fiberglass skimboards and faster on the water and on the wet sand but they are one of the most expensive boards. These boards are more commonly used by professional riders that ride big waves.
There are four essential characteristics specific for riding a variety of waves. The board must be light enough to practically float (skim) on the water, but heavy enough that it will not fly away in the wind. It must be fast, as skimboarders need speed to get to the desired wave and not miss it completely. It must have adequate and appropriate rocker for your desired skimboarding location. It must be flexible according to personal preference based on riding style and ability.
'''Flatland or Inland Skimboards'''
Inland boards are generally made of wood and are easy to find at a local surf or skate shop, depending on your location. Inland boards tend to be made of wood and have a hpl bottom{{clarify|date=May 2016}} and, therefore, are called "woodies" by wave-riding skimboarders. Wood core can boards are quite rugged. They are meant for grinding rails and doing tricks. They stand up well against rocks and shells, obstacles, and general wear, they are great for beginners because they are simple to make and low-price. They are also used by a lot of professional skimboarders and can learn how to do a lot more tricks such as a "Bigger Spin".
There are two basic sides of the spectrum for board types. The “Trick board,” a board where both sides are symmetrical and the shape is even throughout. This makes it ideal for spinning the board and completing tricks due to its symmetry. The “Cruiser board,” a board where the shape follows the same curves as a surfboard and is either slightly pointed or rounded at the top or tip and the back is slightly rounder. The backside of the board can also have a tail. These boards are typically called pintails.
==Industry== {{unreferenced section|date=May 2016}} The increasing international interest in skimboarding has resulted in the development of a competitive industry, catering for the ever-increasing demand for both quality and cheap skimboards. Each company has what they call [[team riders]]. Some famous riders are: Paulo Prietto, a professional skimboarder from California, and Brad Domke, a new rider from Florida which just beat the world record of the biggest wave ridden before, people who skimboard in competitions while representing their company [[sponsor (commercial)|sponsor]] to promote their boards. They usually have an amateur and professional team who are supplied by the manufacturer with skimboards at no or little cost. However, as a pro-rider the company usually pays for all traveling expenses for their riders on competition tours.
==Contests== {{unreferenced section|date=May 2016}} Skimboarding contests are held to establish ranking amongst skimboarders and provide a way for companies to market products. In North America there are two centralized organizations that hold events: United Skim Tour and Skim USA. There are also a lot of minor competitions such as the Virgin River Classic held in St. George Utah. In recent years the United Skim Tour (UST) has focused solely on professional competition while Skim USA has gravitated towards amateur competition. Some events are both Skim USA and UST events, and all Skim USA competitions have a professional division.
In Europe, the European Skimboard League was created in 2009 to promote skimboarding across the world. Its creation has been seen as one of the finest moments in European skimboarding to date. The 2009 League was won by Emanuel (Mega) Embaixador and in 2010 Hugo Santos. The league consists of 4 stages mostly held in the summer months, although UK & Spanish events tend to happen just outside the holiday season. The stages are held in Portugal, France, The UK & Spain, each hosted at one of the best skimboarding locations found anywhere in the world. The UK event is held at Tolcarne Beach in Newquay, Cornwall. Newquay is a location famous for its surfing scene and Tolcarne Beach is known as the UK Wedge to many surfers, bodyboarders & skimboarders.
The DB Dash point Open is a flatland contest that takes place in Federal Way Washington, U.S.A at Dash Point State Park once a year<nowiki/>https://dbskimboards.com/articles/2016-db-pro-skimboard-contest. The Dash Point Pro/Am contest has been running for thirteen years<nowiki/>https://dbskimboards.com/articles/10th-annual-dash-point-proam. The first contest happened in 2003 and the latest in 2016 where Cody Maurer of Utah won first place in the Pro division<nowiki/>https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3F8HcymKw3I. Maurer landed a flawless backside 270 big-spin to front board on a launch ramp to double flat bar set-up. This banger helped him win first place.
In the past The Victoria World Championships determined the World Champion of Professional Skimboarding. The United Skim Tour moved professional skimboarding to a points system in 2012. Most events consist of a set time and date, but, there has been a small movement to start holding waiting period competitions like the Florida Pro/Am held in Vilano Beach, Florida each year, also the DB Pro-AM at Dash Point State Park. The pros all look forward to the first official contest of the year, which until 2013 was held in Cabo San Lucas every spring, but is now held in Brazil. In 2013, Cabo San Lucas was moved to the second contest of the year. The Florida Pro/Am is a skimboarding tournament held each August, on Vilano Beach, Florida. It typically lasts three days, and is the final leg of The Florida Cross Over Tour which includes surfing, skateboarding and skimboarding. The Florida Pro/Am and The Florida Cross-Over Tour are both considered premier skimboarding events. Some well-known skimboarders are Austin Keen, who is the current 2013 UST World Champion, Bill Bryan, Brad Domke, Adrien Raza, Morgan Just, Grady Archbold, James Lovett, Sam Stinnett, Paulo Prietto, Brandon Sears, Brandon Rothe, Jackson Tenney, and Colton Wallace.
Three leading companies are Exile Skimboards, Victoria Skimboards and Zap Skimboards. There are two types of contests; flatland and wave riding contests.
==See also==
*[[Inland skimboarding]]
