{{For|the former AS Monaco ground of the same name|Stade Louis II (1939)}} {{more citations needed|date=September 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2013}} {{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Stade Louis-II | nickname = | image = Panoramio - V&A Dudush - stade Louis II.jpg | image_size = 290px | fullname = | location = [[Fontvieille, Monaco|Fontvieille]], [[Monaco]] | coordinates = | broke_ground = | built = early 1980s (current) | opened = 1939 (original)
25 January 1985 (current) | renovated = | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = | operator = | surface = [[Desso GrassMaster]] | construction_cost = | architect = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | project_manager = | main_contractors = | former_names = | tenants = [[AS Monaco FC|AS Monaco]]
[[Monaco national football team]] | seating_capacity = 18,523 (all-seater) | | dimensions = | scoreboard = }} [[Image:Monaco005.jpg|thumb|A top view of the stadium]] The '''Stade Louis II''' ({{IPA-fr|stad(ə) lwi dø}}) is a [[stadium]] located in the [[Fontvieille, Monaco|Fontvieille]] district of [[Monaco]]. It serves primarily as a venue for [[Association football|football]], being the home of [[AS Monaco FC|AS Monaco]] and the [[Monaco national football team]]. From 1998 to 2012, the stadium hosted the annual [[European Super Cup|UEFA Super Cup]] match.{{cite web|url=http://www.uefa.com/uefasupercup/news/newsid=1644318.html|title=Prague celebrates 2013 Super Cup honour|date=17 June 2011|work=UEFA.com}} The stadium is also used for the [[Herculis]], a [[track and field]] meet of the [[IAAF Diamond League]]. From 2003 to 2005 it hosted the [[IAAF World Athletics Final]], though certain events, such as the [[hammer throw|hammer]], had to be held elsewhere, due to the stadium's relatively small capacity. The original [[Stade Louis II (1939)|Stade Louis II]] was opened in 1939 as the home of [[AS Monaco FC|AS Monaco]]. The new stadium was built in the early 1980s, close to the site of the old stadium on land reclaimed from the sea, opening fully in 1985. {{As of|2016}} the capacity was about 18,500 all seated, about half of the population of Monaco (about 36,371), and more than any other stadium in the country.{{citation needed|date=February 2015}} The vast majority of the stadium's facilities are located underground, with a large car park directly under the pitch (something that has caused some degree of criticism from managers of AS Monaco's opponents in the past over the state of the pitch).{{citation needed|date=February 2015}} The stadium is named after [[Louis II, Prince of Monaco]], who was the [[Prince#Nominal principalities|Sovereign Prince]] of Monaco when the original stadium was built.{{citation needed|date=February 2015}} ==Events== On 29 July 2008, [[Yelena Isinbayeva]] set the women's pole vault world record of 5.04 metres at the ground.{{cite web|title=IAAF Statistics Handbook, 2009 |url=http://www.iaaf.org/mm/document/competitions/competition/05/15/63/20090706014834_httppostedfile_p345-688_11303.pdf |publisher=[[IAAF]] |accessdate=4 April 2014 |deadurl=unfit |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110629134819/http://www.iaaf.org/mm/document/competitions/competition/05/15/63/20090706014834_httppostedfile_p345-688_11303.pdf |archivedate=29 June 2011 }} On 1 July 2011, [[The Eagles]] played at the ground at the [[Wedding of Albert II, Prince of Monaco, and Charlene Wittstock|wedding of Prince Albert II to Charlene Wittstock]].{{cite news|title=Mariage princier : concert au stade Louis II (Princely marriage - concert at the Stade Louis II)|url=http://www.noblesseetroyautes.com/2011/07/mariage-princier-concert-au-stade-louis-ii/|accessdate=4 April 2014|newspaper=Noblesse et Royautés|date=1 July 2011}} [[Image:Stade Louis II.JPG|thumb|200px|right|View of the pitch inside Stade Louis II]] ==Explosion== {{Unreferenced section|date=February 2015}} On 31 May 2004, an explosion, apparently deliberate, caused damage to the Stade Louis II and a neighbouring building, [[La Ruche, Fontvieille]]. No injuries were reported and responsibility for the attack remained unclear. The damage, while relatively extensive to portions of the fabric of the buildings, was verified as not having affected the buildings' respective structures. The Government of Monaco assumed responsibility for repairs to the damage caused by the explosion, without preempting the results of expert investigations, which continued. This explosion constituted a rare exception to the principality's long-established reputation for safety and absence of violence. ==Facilities== [[Image:Salle Gaston Médecin.JPG|thumb|200px|right|The [[Salle Gaston Médecin]] indoor arena, which is used by the [[AS Monaco Basket|AS Monaco]] basketball club]] The [[Salle Gaston Médecin]] indoor arena is located under the stands of the football stadium. Salle Gaston Médecin is able to host [[basketball]], [[volleyball]], and [[handball]] games, as well as [[judo]] and [[fencing]] matches, and [[Olympic weightlifting|weightlifting]] and [[gymnastics]] competitions. Stade Louis II, containing a large office complex, also houses the [[International University of Monaco]] (IUM), which specializes in business education. ==See also== * [[Geography of Monaco]] {{Coord|43|43|39|N|7|24|56|E|type:landmark_scale:2000_region:MC|display=title}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{commonscat}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070113004225/http://monaco.net/communiques/2004050201.htm monaco.net] * [http://www.stadiumguide.com/louis2/ Stadium Guide Article] {{S-start}} {{Succession box | title = [[UEFA Super Cup]]
Single-match Venue | before = Two-legged matches| | after = [[Eden Arena]]
[[Prague]]| | years = '''[[1998 UEFA Super Cup|1998]]–[[2012 UEFA Super Cup|2012]]''' }} {{S-end}} {{Ligue 1 venues}} {{AS Monaco FC}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2010}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Louis Ii}} [[Category:AS Monaco FC|Stade Louis II]] [[Category:Fontvieille]] [[Category:Sports venues in Monaco]] [[Category:Football venues in Monaco]] [[Category:Athletics (track and field) venues in Monaco]] [[Category:National stadiums]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1939]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1985]] [[Category:1939 establishments in Monaco|Stade Louis II]]

{{Infobox motorsport venue |name = Syracuse Mile |nicknames = |time = |location = [[Great New York State Fair|New York State Fairgrounds]], [[Syracuse, New York]] |coordinates = |image = |image_caption = |capacity = |FIA_grade = |owner = |operator = |broke_ground = |opened = 1826 (harness)
1903 (automobile) |closed = 2015 |construction_cost= |architect = |former_names = |events = [[Super DIRTcar Series|Super DIRT Week]] |layout1 = oval |surface = [[dirt track racing|dirt]] |length_km = 1.6 |length_mi = 1 | miles_first = true |turns = 4 |banking = |record_time = |record_driver = |record_team = |record_year = |record_class = |embedded = |website = }} The '''Syracuse Mile''' was a {{convert|1|mile|km|adj=on}} [[Dirt track racing|dirt]] [[Oval racing|oval]] [[Stock car racing|raceway]] located at the [[Great New York State Fair|New York State Fairgrounds]] in [[Syracuse, New York|Syracuse]], [[New York (state)|New York]]. Originally built for [[harness racing]] in 1826, the first auto race was run in 1903, making it the second oldest auto racing facility in United States history. The track and grandstands were torn down in 2016 by state government officials with the plan to modernize facilities. {{cite web|title = The history of the Moody Mile| url=https://360nitro.tv/articles/2014/10/01/the-history-of-the-moody-mile |publisher=360nitro.tv|accessdate=November 1, 2017}} ==Harness racing== The Syracuse Mile hosted [[harness racing]] from its opening until 2005. The [[Hambletonian Stakes]] were held from 1926 through 1929. {{cite web|title = The Early Years| url=https://www.hambletonian.com/hambletonian-history.html |publisher=The Hambletonian Society, Inc|accessdate=November 1, 2017}} In the early 1970s, a new 16,000-seat grandstand was built as part of an unsuccessful attempt to bring back the Hambletonian Stakes. [https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/36634141/ The Post-Standard (1976, February 23, p.15)] ==Auto racing== In 1900, a $10,000 bid was awarded to build a dirt track suitable for auto racing on the perimeter of the harness track. {{cite web|title = Place of 'mystery, lore and legend'| url=http://www.syracuse.com/kirst/index.ssf/2015/09/place_of_mystery_lore_and_legend_in_farewell_to_moody_mile_where_is_deep_respect.html |publisher=Syracuse.com|accessdate=November 1, 2017}} The first auto race at the track was held in 1903, and won by [[Barney Oldfield]] in his "Baby Bullet". Oldfield averaged more than 60 mph in a lap around the mile. Syracuse was one of the several tracks one mile in length that made up the [[American Automobile Association|AAA]] [[AAA Contest Board|national championship]]. {{cite web|title =Farewell to the ‘Moody Mile’|url=https://www.thestar.com/autos/2015/10/09/farewell-to-the-moody-mile-and-was-he-really-going-100-miles-an-hour.html|publisher=TheStar.com|accessdate=November 1, 2017}} From 1925 to 1971 the Fairgrounds Board contracted with former Indianapolis driver [[Ira Vail]] to promote auto racing.{{cite web|title=Fourth National Sprint Car Hall of Fame Inductions|url =http://www.sprintcarhof.com/FileGet.aspx?ID=189|publisher=National Sprint Car Hall of Fame & Museum|accessdate=November 1, 2017}} With Vail's promotion, drivers such as Mario Andretti, A.J. Foyt and Al Unser competed for wins during one of the Indianapolis 500's golden era's, putting the Syracuse Mile in the national spotlight. On Labor Day 1949 the sportsman modified stock cars took to the track. The New York State Fair Championship then became a Labor Day a tradition that lasted until 2003.{{cite web|title =Fairgrounds' track faces final memories of long racing history| url=http://www.syracuse.com/motorsports/index.ssf/2015/03/fairgrounds_track_faces_final_memories_of_long_racing_history.html |publisher=Syracuse.com |accessdate=November 1, 2017}} [[Floyd, New York]] driver Cliff Kotary reigned as State Fair Champion for six straight years (1960-1965). {{cite web|title =Cliff Kotary dies at 91| url=http://www.uticaod.com/article/20101230/news/312309920 |publisher=Utica Observer Dispatch |accessdate=April 23, 2018}} In 1955 the first of three races for what is now referred to as the Monster Energy NASCAR Cup Series at the fairgrounds. Tim Flock, Buck Baker and Gwyn Staley were victorious in the three events held from 55-57. {{cite web|title = The history of the Moody Mile| url=https://360nitro.tv/articles/2014/10/01/the-history-of-the-moody-mile |publisher=360nitro.tv|accessdate=November 1, 2017}} NASCAR's Convertible Stock Series also competed in 56 and 57. Curtis Turner and Possum Jones were victorious in those events. In 1972, [[Central New York Raceway Park |Glenn Donnelly]] began promoting races at the fairgrounds adding to the Labor Day event with races on the Fourth of July and Columbus Day weekend. The October race became [[Super Dirt Week|Super DIRT Week]], and continued at the Fairgrounds until 2015. {{cite web|title =Fairgrounds' track faces final memories of long racing history| url=http://www.syracuse.com/motorsports/index.ssf/2015/03/fairgrounds_track_faces_final_memories_of_long_racing_history.html |publisher=Syracuse.com |accessdate=November 1, 2017}} [[Buzzie Reutimann]] beat NASCAR Hall of Famer [[Jerry Cook]] for the 1972 Championship. {{cite web|title=Syracuse's Moody Mile Hosting Final Stock Car Race|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/motor/2015/10/07/syracuse-moody-mile-closing-final-race-finale-new-york-state-fairgrounds/73560972/|publisher=USA Today|accessdate=August 2, 2018}} [[Brett Hearn]] of [[Kinnelon, New Jersey]], became the all-time win leader at the "Moody Mile," after claiming 6 Super Dirt Week main event victories and 6 "358 Modified" triumphs, the final coming in 2014.{{cite web|title =Brett Hearn Wins Record 6th Title| url=http://blog.syracuse.com/motorsports/2012/10/hearn_wins_record_sixth_super_dirt_title_in_rain-delayed_rain.html|publisher=Syracuse.com |accessdate=April 23, 2018}}{{cite web|title =Brett Hearn Wins 358 Modified Championship| url=http://blog.syracuse.com/motorsports/2014/10/super_dirt_week_2014_brett_hearn_wins_salute_to_the_troops_358-modified_championship.html|publisher=Syracuse.com |accessdate=April 23, 2018}} ==The “Moody Mile”== The race track was nicknamed "The Moody Mile" after driver Wes Moody turned a 100-mile-per-hour lap in 1970. {{cite web|title =Farewell to the ‘Moody Mile’|url=https://www.thestar.com/autos/2015/10/09/farewell-to-the-moody-mile-and-was-he-really-going-100-miles-an-hour.html|publisher=TheStar.com|accessdate=November 1, 2017}} ==Closure== In 2015, New York Governor Andrew Cuomo announced a sweeping redesign of the fairgrounds that included taking out what was the 16,000-seat grandstand and mile-long dirt track. {{cite web|title =Development plans may doom the dirt mile track at Syracuse, New York|url=https://www.hemmings.com/blog/2015/03/19/development-plans-may-doom-the-dirt-mile-track-at-syracuse-new-york/|publisher=Hemmings Daily|accessdate=November 5, 2017}} The last stock car race was held that year on Columbus day weekend. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[https://blackflag.jalopnik.com/were-losing-one-of-americas-best-dirt-tracks-and-its-he-1736199776 “Black Flag:We're Losing One Of America's Best Dirt Tracks And It's Heartbreaking.” Japolink.com ] {{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Weingart Stadium | image=[[Image:WeingartStadium1.jpg|250px|Weingart Stadium]] | location= 1301 Avenida Cesar Chavez Monterey Park CA 91754 (on campus of [[East Los Angeles College]]) | opened=1951 | owner=East Los Angeles College | construction_cost = $3.1 million | tenants=[[East Los Angeles College]] (football, men's and women's soccerhttp://elaccampusnews.com/2012/05/02/stadium-holds-plenty-of-history/) ([[California Community College Athletic Association|CCCAA]]) (1951–present)
* [[Cal State Los Angeles Golden Eagles|CSULA Diablos]] (1958–1961, 1970–1971)
[[Los Angeles Aztecs]] ([[North American Soccer League (1968–84)|NASL]]) (1974)
[[Hockey at the 1984 Summer Olympics|Olympic Field Hockey]] ([[International Olympic Committee|IOC]]) (1984)
[[Los Angeles Salsa]] ([[American Professional Soccer League|APSL]]) (1993–1994)
[[East LA Classic]] ([[California Interscholastic Federation|CIF]]) | seating_capacity=22,355 }} '''Weingart Stadium''' (formerly '''ELAC Stadium''') is a 22,355-capacity multi-purpose stadium located at [[East Los Angeles College]], in [[Monterey Park, California]]. It was built in 1951 at a cost of $3.1 million, and following renovations in 1984 it was renamed after philanthropist [[Ben Weingart]]. The stadium played host to all [[1984 Summer Olympics|1984]] Olympic [[Field hockey at the 1984 Summer Olympics|field hockey]] matches.[http://www.la84foundation.org/6oic/OfficialReports/1984/1984v1pt1.pdf 1984 Summer Olympics official report.] Volume 1. Part 1. pp. 83-6. US Field Hockey played a home game here in 1990. The [[Los Angeles Salsa]] [[soccer]] club called Weingart home in the early 1990s. It is one of the only mid-size stadiums in the western United States that is retrofitted with turf-playing surface certified by the [[Federation International de Football Association]] (FIFA). Today, although it remains home to the [[East Los Angeles College]] football team, it is best known as the site of the annual [[Garfield High School (Los Angeles County, California)|Garfield High School]]–[[Theodore Roosevelt High School (Los Angeles)|Roosevelt High School]] football game, better known as the [[East LA Classic|East Los Angeles Classic]], which has been responsible for the Stadium's largest crowds, numbering over 25,000. Commencement ceremonies for local high schools such as [[Schurr High School]] in [[Montebello, California|Montebello]], [[Alhambra High School (Alhambra, California)|Alhambra High School]] in [[Alhambra]] and [[Garfield High School (Los Angeles County, California)|Garfield High School]] in [[Los Angeles]] are held at Weingart Stadium. ==Usage in films== In the film via Evel Kenvil it was used to simulate a stadium in Mexico were Evel did I motorcycle jump. A Mexican concert was used to draw a crowd in to fill the stadium for the shoot In the film ''[[Forrest Gump]]'', special effects were used to turn ELAC's Weingart Stadium into the [[University of Alabama]]'s football stadium. Using digital FX, a small crowd which was filmed at ELAC, appears to fill the entire stadium. On October 19, 2013, during halftime of the ELAC and [[Victor Valley College]] game, the stadium was used as the home field of Gotham City University for the film ''[[Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice]]'' featuring the superheroes [[Superman]] and [[Batman]]. The scene involved a football game between Gotham City University and rival Metropolis State University. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.lasports.org/lafacilities/display.php?s=Stadium&id=17 Weingart Stadium at LA Sports Council] * [https://maps.google.com/maps?ie=UTF8&z=18&ll=34.042681,-118.151656&spn=0.003463,0.005032&t=h&om=1 Weingart Stadium at Google Maps] {{coord|34|2|34.30|N|118|9|6.13|W|display=title}} {{Cal State Los Angeles Diablos football navbox}} {{Los Angeles Aztecs}} {{1984 Summer Olympic venues}} {{Olympic venues field hockey}} [[Category:Cal State Los Angeles Diablos football]] [[Category:College track and field venues in the United States]] [[Category:Defunct college football venues]] [[Category:Los Angeles Aztecs sports facilities|w]] [[Category:Los Angeles Salsa]] [[Category:Eastside Los Angeles]] [[Category:Sports venues in Los Angeles County, California]] [[Category:Sports in Monterey Park, California]] [[Category:Soccer venues in California]] [[Category:Venues of the 1984 Summer Olympics]] [[Category:Olympic field hockey venues]] [[Category:North American Soccer League (1968–84) stadiums]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1951]] [[Category:1951 establishments in California]] [[Category:Athletics (track and field) venues in California]] [[Category:American football venues in California]] [[Category:High school football venues in California]]

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2016}} {{Use British English|date=February 2016}} '''William (Will) Palmer''' (born late 1736 and christened 9 January 1737 in [[Coulsdon]], [[Surrey]]; died February 1790 and buried 8 February 1790 in Coulsdon) was a famous English [[cricket]]er who played in the 1760s and 1770s.
Most of Palmer's career was before cricket's statistical record began in the [[1772 English cricket season]] so relatively little is known of him. He played in first-class matches until 1776. He was a noted batsman in his day and had some fine innings in 1773 especially.
Palmer was a member of [[Coulsdon Cricket Club]] in Surrey but he also played a few times for Kent. In recorded matches from 1772, he made 20 known first-class appearances and took 2 catches but no wickets. He scored 478 runs in 37 innings with a top score of 68, which is a very good record considering the prevailing conditions that were entirely in the favour of the bowlers. He made 2 known scores of 50-plus and 4 more that were 25-plus.<ref name=LL>{{cite web |url=http://www.jl.sl.btinternet.co.uk/stampsite/cricket/ladstolords/1761.html |title=From Lads to Lord's – profile |accessdate=2009-07-31 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121010153249/http://www.jl.sl.btinternet.co.uk/stampsite/cricket/ladstolords/1761.html#palmer |archivedate=10 October 2012 |df=dmy-all }}.</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [https://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Players/77/77401/77401.html CricketArchive record of William Palmer]
==Further reading== * [[Arthur Haygarth]], ''Scores & Biographies, Volume 1 (1744-1826)'', Lillywhite, 1862
{{DEFAULTSORT:Palmer, William}} [[Category:English cricketers]] [[Category:Surrey cricketers]] [[Category:English cricketers of 1701 to 1786]] [[Category:1737 births]] [[Category:1790 deaths]] [[Category:People from Coulsdon]] [[Category:Kent cricketers]] [[Category:Non-international England cricketers]]

{{Infobox venue | stadium_name = Witter Field | nickname = | image = | fullname = | location = 521 Lincoln St, Wisconsin Rapids, WI 54494http://northwoodsleague.com/wisconsin-woodchucks/more/ballpark/ | coordinates = | broke_ground = | built = 1928 | opened = 1928 | renovated = 1950, 2010 | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = Wisconsin Rapids | operator = | surface = Grass | construction_cost = | architect = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | project_manager = | main_contractors = | former_names = Lincoln Athletic Field | tenants = [[Wisconsin Rapids Rafters]] (2010-Present)
[[Wisconsin Rapids Twins]] (1964-1983)
[[Wisconsin Rapids Senators]] (1963)
[[Wisconsin Rapids White Sox]] (1941-42; 1946-53) | seating_capacity = 4000 (1941) 3000 (1983),https://www.baseball-reference.com/register/park.cgi?id=WI031 1588 (current)http://northwoodsleague.com/wisconsin-rapids-rafters/team/ballpark/ | dimensions = (LF-CF-RF): 320-385-320https://www.baseball-reference.com/register/park.cgi?id=WI031 320 L, 375 C, 320 R (current)http://northwoodsleague.com/wisconsin-rapids-rafters/team/ballpark/ | scoreboard = }} '''Witter Field''' is a baseball [[ballpark]] located at 521 Lincoln Street in [[Wisconsin Rapids, Wisconsin]], United States. It was built in 1928.[http://www.raftersbaseball.com/history.html RaftersBaseball.com] It served as the home park for multiple [[minor league]] teams: the [[Wisconsin Rapids White Sox]], [[Wisconsin Rapids Senators]] and [[Wisconsin Rapids Twins]].[https://www.baseball-reference.com/minors/team.cgi?city=Wisconsin%20Rapids&state=WI&country=US BR Minors] Currently, it hosts the [[Northwoods League]]'s [[Wisconsin Rapids Rafters]] and youth teams. ==Witter Field History== The ballpark was home to the [[Wisconsin Rapids White Sox]] (1941–42; 1946–53) of the Class-D [[Wisconsin State League]].http://northwoodsleague.com/wisconsin-rapids-rafters/team/ballpark/ The League folded after the 1953 season,http://www.digitalballparks.com/MWL/Witter_640_6.html leaving Witter without professional baseball until a new team in the Class-A [[Midwest League]] started play. The [[Wisconsin Rapids Senators]] (1963) and [[Wisconsin Rapids Twins]] (1964-1983) would play for the next two decades.https://www.baseball-reference.com/register/park.cgi?id=WI031 Following the 1983 season, the franchise moved to [[Simmons Field]] in [[Kenosha, Wisconsin]].http://www.digitalballparks.com/MWL/Witter_640_20.html In 2010, baseball returned, as the current tenant, the [[Wisconsin Rapids Rafters]] of the summer collegiate [[Northwoods League]] began play in June, 2010.http://northwoodsleague.com/wisconsin-rapids-rafters/team/ballpark/ The park was built in 1928 and dedicated in 1934.http://northwoodsleague.com/wisconsin-rapids-rafters/team/ballpark/ The site housed the Lincoln High School facility, beginning in 1902 and the field was called "Lincoln Athletic Field" until 1940 when it became "Witter Field" in honor of Isaac Witter.http://wisconsinrapidslegionbaseball.org/witter.html The wooden grandstand bleachers were replaced in 1950. 227 seats from the demolished [[Milwaukee County Stadium]] were installed in 2010.http://northwoodsleague.com/wisconsin-rapids-rafters/team/ballpark/ From 2005-2008 Witter Field hosted the youth WIAC state baseball tournament.http://wisconsinrapidslegionbaseball.org/witter.html On July 18, 2011, Witter Field hosted the Northwoods League All-Star Game. [[Baseball Hall of Fame]] inductee [[Paul Molitor]] was present for All-Star festivities.http://northwoodsleague.com/wisconsin-rapids-rafters/team/ballpark/ ==The site today== It is currently the home to local High School baseball, [[American Legion Baseball|Legion Baseball]] and hosts the [[Northwoods League]]'s [[Wisconsin Rapids Rafters]].http://northwoodsleague.com/wisconsin-rapids-rafters/team/ballpark/ The site also contains tennis courts, ice skating, a warming house, a football field and a skate park.http://visitwisrapids.com/witter-field/ ==Notable players== The park has hosted numerous [[Major League Baseball|Major League]] alumni, some of note include: {{div col|colwidth=22em}} * [[Ben Heller]] (2012) * [[Allan Anderson (baseball)|Allan Anderson]] (1983) [[List of Major League Baseball annual ERA leaders]]; '''1988 AL ERA Leader''' * [[Mark Davidson]] (1982–83) * [[Mark Portugal]] (1982) * [[Rich Yett]] (1981) * [[Jim Eisenreich]] (1980–81) 15 MLB Seasons; First Recipient of [[Tony Conigliaro Award]] * [[Gary Gaetti]] (1980) gg; 4 x GG; 2 x MLB AS; '''1987 ALCS MVP''' * [[Kent Hrbek]] (1980) MLB AS * [[Rick Stelmaszek]] (1978-80 MGR) * [[Bud Bulling]] (1975–76) * [[John Castino]] (1976) '''1979 AL Rookie of the Year''' * [[Rick Sofield]] (1976) MLB Player, Coach * [[Jerry Garvin]] (1974) * [[Gary Ward (outfielder)|Gary Ward]] (1974) 2 x MLB AS * [[Alvis Woods]] (1974) * [[Randy Bass]] (1973) * [[Tom Johnson (baseball, born 1951)|Tom Johnson]] (1972) * [[Glenn Borgmann]] (1971) * [[Bill Campbell (baseball)|Bill Campbell]] (1971) MLB AS; '''1977 AL Saves Leader''' * [[Jim Hughes (1970s pitcher)|Jim Hughes]] (1971) * [[Dave McKay (baseball)|Dave McKay]] (1971) MLB Player/Coach * [[Johnny Goryl]] (1970, 1973–75, MGR) MLB MGR * [[Steve Barber]] (1969) 2 x MLB AS * [[Rick Dempsey]] (1968–69) '''1983 World Series MVP''' * [[Bill Zepp]] (1968) * [[Steve Braun (baseball)|Steve Braun]] (1967) * [[Tom Hall (baseball)|Tom Hall]] (1967) * [[Charlie Manual]] (1967, MGR 1983) MLB MGR: 1000 wins; '''MGR: 2008 World Series Champion - Philadelphia Phillies''' * [[Graig Nettles]] (1966) 2 x GG; 6 x MLB AS '''1976 AL Home Run Leader''';'''1981 ALCS MVP''' * [[George Mitterwald]] (1965, 1968) * [[Pat Kelly (outfielder)|Pat Kelly]] (1964) MLB AS * [[Jim French (baseball)|Jim French]] (1963) * [[Wayne Terwilliger]] (1963, MGR) * [[Johnny Schaive]] (1953) * [[Jim Landis]] (1952) 5 x GG in CF; 2 x MLB AS * [[Glen Stewart]] (1949) * [[Bill Fischer (baseball)|Bill Fischer]] (1942) * [[Cy Buker]] (1942) * [[Max Patkin]] (1941) Long Time baseball entertainer, featured in ''Bull Durham''; '''1988 [[King of Baseball]]''' {{div col end}} ==References== {{reflist}} {{coord|44.385493|-89.820621|type:landmark_globe:earth_region:WI|display=title}} {{NWL ballparks}} [[Category:Buildings and structures in Wood County, Wisconsin]] [[Category:Baseball venues in Wisconsin]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Wood County, Wisconsin]] [[Category:1928 establishments in Wisconsin]] [[Category:Midwest League ballparks]] [[Category:Sports in Wisconsin Rapids, Wisconsin]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1928]]
